He believed he was more worldly wise than his mother, while her younger son, Daniel, was more understanding of her mistakes because he made them too. Dan might forget to pass on the message to Kristina.

Eventually, the line began to move, and Violet approached a window to hand over her travel documents and prepare to board. Her heart sank further when she entered the ship’s foyer, which looked like a not-so-grand hotel trying too hard. There were shiny fake wood panels, extravagant chandeliers, polished brass, and carpets that looked like those found in airports. 

Violet followed the signs to the ‘Elevators’, which were lined with mirrors and packed with tired passengers who might have preferred not to see their reflections. She was squeezed against the side of the lift as it moved up, stopping at each floor to let people out. Finally, on the twelfth floor, she stepped out into freedom. Thankfully, her room had the balcony she had requested. She had been worried about what to say if it didn’t. Ignoring Annie’s advice to wait for a last-minute deal, she had decided to pay the highest price she could afford to ensure she had a view of the sea.

Text: 

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he had no idea he was about to uncover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was searching for images for a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago. Instead, he discovered 30,000 photographs taken by Maier, a talented street photographer known for her striking images. Since then, Maloof has built a collection of Maier’s life and work. In his home attic, he keeps her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm films and audiotapes.

One morning, Maloof looked around at his collection, realizing he was on the brink of something significant, all due to luck. “When I bought this, I had no idea what it was,” he said. “I’m a third-generation flea market seller and could have easily sold it all to someone else.” For a while, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been piecing together details of Maier’s life. They reached out to families who had employed her as a nanny and spoke with staff from the shop where she developed her film.

Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. She returned to New York in 1951 and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier was known to be a private person with a unique personality, always carrying a camera. She wore large coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. “On her day off, the camera was always around her neck, and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night,” said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. “I remember her as a private person but someone with strong opinions about movies and politics.”

Maier was knowledgeable about theater and film. Although she was not very social, she would walk the streets with her camera and engage with people, some of whom she interviewed on audiotape. She seemed to be dedicated to her “second job” of documenting the world around her. “She was a true artist who followed her dreams,” said Rydzon. “She didn’t let anything stop her.” Maier’s work is pure art; she did not create it for commercial reasons. Her photographs often focus on women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract subjects.

“What is fascinating about Vivian is the number of interesting pictures,” said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style independently. “Was Vivian sophisticated enough to do this, or did she borrow ideas from those before her?” Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever sort through all the negatives, which he has stored in three tall, fireproof cabinets. Interestingly, he had no real interest in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof began taking his own pictures.

“As I improved as a photographer and revisited her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It’s the people, the street scenes, the overall composition,” he said. “There was so much more to her work than I thought, and I realized I was sitting on something more important than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to make her name known and to get Vivian Maier into the history books.”

When a novel is called ambitious, it often suggests that it has not fully succeeded. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK during a time when her book was very successful, and she was at the center of a lot of media attention. Despite being in her twenties, she appeared calm. She had just arrived from Germany and was flying back to New Zealand the next day. 

She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass, and the official asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. The Luminaries takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s, where a series of crimes have occurred, leading a council of 12 men to come together to solve them. The plot becomes very complex. Catton intended to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past provided many opportunities for her characters to face complications and misunderstandings. 

At over 800 pages, the book is “big by necessity” because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a fair chance to shine. When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she responded thoughtfully. “It’s nice coming from a small country because everyone feels like the success is partly theirs. There’s a family-like feeling at home; I received a lot of support from other people’s grandmas.” She also mentioned that it annoys her when people assume her book is not a philosophical work.

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral, with each part being half the length of the previous one. This structure makes the story speed up as it progresses. I asked if it matters whether readers notice these patterns. She said, “I wanted to create a book with structural patterns that didn’t matter, but if you cared, you could find them.” Despite its experimental structure, The Luminaries remains an exciting murder mystery with a captivating plot. Interestingly, she did not plan the story in advance. “I would write myself into a corner and then see how creative I could be in getting out of that situation,” she said. 

One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers. We also discussed her love for television dramas, noting how The Luminaries uses cliff-hangers, multiple viewpoints, and dialogue. I asked if she would consider screenwriting. “That could be pretty cool,” she replied, her enthusiasm evident. She became animated when discussing her writing and New Zealand. “I notice that when I come to Britain, the landscape of my imagination changes just by being in a different place. I understand why writers leave New Zealand for more populated areas, to experience the energy of other people.” For now, New Zealand will remain her home, and I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.

Text: 

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead spent his time either building things in his dad’s garage or playing the guitar. For the last forty years, he has made a living by handcrafting steel-string acoustic guitars. He expresses his fascination with the guitar, wondering how two pieces of wood can create such beautiful sounds and how different types of wood can change the sound. Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar at the age of eleven and later wanted to learn the bass guitar when he was sixteen. Instead of saving money for one, he decided to build it himself. He studied how different shapes and types of wood affect sound and how to combine them.

The bass guitar was the first instrument Jonny built from scratch, but he had been making model boats and planes with his brothers for a long time. His father taught them how to use tools, and Jonny had also customized and repaired instruments for his friends. Although his bass guitar turned out well, he hadn’t thought about a career in guitar-making at that time. He was also interested in painting and sculpture, so after finishing school, he chose to study architecture at university. He liked design, and being an architect seemed like a good choice. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out because he felt too different from the others. 

Leaving university helped him realize that guitar-making was a form of sculpture that involved creating sound. He thought it might be a more practical career than pure art because he would be making things that people use. Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he worked part-time cleaning windows to support himself. His early guitars were sold for just the cost of materials, but as he gained a reputation as a skilled guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, after almost forty years, Jonny describes his work as “still scratching a living.” He can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income.

In the beginning, it was important for him to get known. He attended music festivals most weekends to let musicians try his guitars and encourage them to spread the word. He also had to learn how to price his instruments, as he initially struggled with this aspect of the business. Jonny believes that it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. When he started, many people thought that only American-made acoustic guitars were valuable, even though the UK has always had good instrument-making courses. Now, UK-made guitars have gained the recognition they deserve.

Jonny thinks that valuable skills can be learned in classes, and he encourages new instrument-makers to take these courses. However, he also believes that there is no substitute for learning through experience. He advises looking at other instruments to see what works and what doesn’t. For example, if the back of a guitar is too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. He believes that being self-taught allows you to learn in many different ways, while being taught by someone else may limit you to just one method.

Text: 

When discussing English conversation, we often start with the weather. This is a common tradition, and I will quote the famous 18th-century writer Dr. Johnson, who said, "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This statement is still true today, just as it was over two hundred years ago. However, many commentators stop here or struggle to explain why the English seem so focused on the weather. They often make a mistake by thinking that our discussions about the weather are genuinely about the weather itself. They believe that English people talk about the weather because they find it interesting.

For instance, the American writer Bill Bryson points out that English weather is not particularly exciting. He notes that in England, we do not experience extreme weather events like tornadoes or blizzards, which are common in other places. In response, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman argues that English weather is indeed interesting. He believes that the English fascination with the weather is not about strong feelings; rather, it is about its unpredictability. He states that while we may not have tropical storms, living on the edge of an ocean means we can never be sure what the weather will be like.

From my research, I believe that both Bryson and Paxman miss the main point: our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather. Instead, talking about the weather is a way for English people to connect with each other. For example, phrases like "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" are not genuine questions about the weather; they are common greetings or ways to start a conversation. In this sense, English weather talk is similar to "social grooming" among monkeys, who spend time grooming each other to bond socially.

There are specific situations where weather talk is used. Some writers claim that English people talk about the weather all the time, but this is not accurate. In reality, there are three main contexts for weather talk: as a simple greeting, as a way to break the ice before discussing other topics, or as a fallback topic when conversations stall and there is an awkward silence. This frequent use of weather talk can give outsiders the impression that English people are obsessed with it. An English conversation might start with a weather greeting, include some ice-breaking weather talk, and then return to weather topics when the conversation slows down. This is why many people, including some English commentators, think that English people must be very interested in the weather.

Alice Leader stood in front of the remains of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds what an amazing engineering achievement it was for the Romans to build something 120 km long and 5 meters high around 1900 years ago. The students were interested in this trip, choosing it over more glamorous tours to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they wanted to know why the Wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not good enough. Unable to find a suitable historical novel to provide context about life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After retiring from teaching for 31 years, Alice began her new career as an author in 2001. 

Having had a successful teaching career, Alice felt she was taking a big step into the unknown. She compared teaching to acting, saying it was physically demanding, while writing was exciting but less exhausting. Her former colleagues envied her because she still connected with children through her fiction. Alice’s main goal for her novels is to fill a gap in children’s literature. She noted that much of today’s adolescent fiction focuses on negative experiences, which, while well-written, often presents dark realities or total fantasy, like Harry Potter. Her books aim to be different.

Alice always taught English and History together, using lessons about ancient Greece alongside the novel "Tale of Troy." She is motivated by her love for children and is fascinated by the moment when a child goes from being bored to interested, and from not understanding to understanding. She enjoys the challenge of engaging bored children. 

Her decision to write her first novel was inspired by the realization that her two sons were leaving home, creating an "empty nest," and a suggestion from her head teacher to attend a creative writing course. Initially, Alice was hesitant, thinking she didn’t need the course after 25 years of teaching. However, she had to submit her best piece of fiction to be accepted, and just days before the course, she quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their unborn child. After three hours and 30 pages, she submitted it and was accepted.

During the course, her classmates analyzed her work and encouraged her to publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing ability, she asked her school’s head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice’s husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and his help in editing her novel was crucial. Alice believes they complement each other; he focuses on improving her writing, while she tends to add more scenes. This difference highlights the roles of a fiction writer and an editor.

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to participate in a special race. This race would have Jonny racing in a car on the roads, while Alistair would race on a mountain bike across the countryside. The race took place in the beautiful and rugged Yorkshire Dales in northern England. 

As they prepared to start, Jonny expressed his excitement, saying, “I’ve never done anything like this before! These roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold, so I’ll be warm in the car.” Alistair, dressed in full winter cycling gear, was also eager. He joked about Jonny’s driving skills, saying, “I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up.”

The race began at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and would finish at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is about 350 meters high. While the car could handle the distance easily, Alistair faced a tough start with a steep incline. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair quickly sped away on his bike, while Jonny got into his car and started driving. The question was, who would reach the finish line first?

Jonny’s confidence was quickly challenged. Just 15 seconds into his drive, he encountered a large tractor blocking the road. He complained to the cameraman, “If Alistair beats me, it’s all down to this farmer!” After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving, while Alistair struggled with the steep hill. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the slope, passing walls and fences, while sheep watched him curiously.

Finally, Alistair reached the top of the hill. With the sun shining and open land ahead, he began to pick up speed. Meanwhile, Jonny faced another challenge. The narrow roads in the villages of Yorkshire were not designed for fast driving. He had to slow down to navigate a tight corner and then drive through a stream that had formed on the road. Once he was clear of the last village, he raced towards the finish line.

Neither brother knew how close they were to each other. As Jonny accelerated down the final stretch to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road. He pushed hard, and as he reached the finish line, he suddenly stopped and looked up, asking the crowd, “Is he here?” When they said no, he raised his arms in celebration, shouting, “Yes!”

Moments later, Jonny arrived in his car and stepped out. “Well done,” he said, feeling disappointed. “I’m gutted.”

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your own shot. The well-kept grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a calm atmosphere that protects you from the outside world. This silence helps my game. What I struggle with most in a tennis match is to focus only on the game and the point I’m playing. The silence of Centre Court is broken by loud applause and cheers when a point ends. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t realize that there are fifteen thousand people watching every move my opponent and I make. I am so focused that I don’t think about the millions watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, taught me from a young age that this was the most important tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing with my friends my dream of playing there one day and winning. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not too hard. I was just happy to have made it that far after turning twenty. Federer won easily, more easily than if I had believed in myself more. But my loss in 2007 was devastating. I knew I could have done better; it was not my skill that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and let it slip away. Toni, who is usually tough on me, surprisingly told me there was no reason to cry and that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand; I felt this was my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment matters, but some moments matter more, and I had missed a big one in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to ease my pain. However, he turned out to be right. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I had learned from my defeat; this time, my mindset would be strong. The best sign that I was ready was my belief that I would win. The night before the final, at dinner with family and friends, we avoided talking about the match. I didn’t tell them not to mention it, but they understood that I was already mentally preparing for the game. From that moment until the match started, that mental space was mine alone.'

Text: In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, “I am living in the Africa I have always longed for.” This woman was Jane Goodall, and she would spend most of her life in Africa as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, the National Geographic Society in Britain helped make her famous by publishing articles and documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including popular children’s books and the 1971 bestseller *In the Shadow of Man*, which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements. Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on sentimental aspects and do not fully capture her work. She has been portrayed in various ways: as an adventurous girl, a privileged woman who wanted to live with wild animals, and a determined feminist. These portrayals can diminish her true contributions. 

Based on the number of academic references to her research, the success of her students in biology, and the extensive data from her forty-year study, Jane Goodall should be recognized as a pioneering zoologist. More simply, she opened our eyes to the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or that they used tools, like humans. We also did not realize that chimpanzees share similar emotions with us or that their social structures are surprisingly similar to ours. Goodall discovered that chimpanzee communities in Africa have unique cultural traditions. Her book, *The Chimpanzees of Gombe* (1986), is the most important work in chimpanzee research and serves as the first encyclopedia on the subject. Her long-term study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and influenced how we view ourselves as humans.

Even as a child, there were signs of the person she would become. One clear example happened in the autumn of 1939 when she was just five years old. One day, Jane disappeared, and her family called the police to help find her. After a frantic search, she reappeared alone, with straw in her hair and clothes. When her mother asked where she had been, Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she had crawled into a henhouse, hidden in the straw, and stayed still for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey as a biologist.

Text: 

In our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voices of a playful 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to fans of children’s TV shows and cartoons, as well as those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she explains, “so I had to quickly learn how to pronounce many medical terms.” 

Shirley shares what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even well-known ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there’s more to it. You need to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions because of their fame, but often they don’t get the roles because they are too used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley joined a drama course, hoping for a traditional acting career. During the course, she occasionally worked singing jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she recalls, “the studio manager suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a major role.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character, her brother, and her mother.”

Adult female actors often provide the voices for young boys and girls because their voices are lighter than those of male actors. Hiring child performers involves complicated procedures and many forms, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds and to vary her voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my experience helps,” she says. “I’ve learned that the trick is to smile while you talk – it makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference.”

The competition for voiceover work is intense, and having a good showreel – a recording that showcases what an artist can do – is crucial. “It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley advises. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached the top of her field through determination as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending “specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.” She also believes a love for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she plays. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific American voice, for example, it can take over me, and I’ll speak like that for hours, maybe even days,” she says. “My children have grown up hearing their mom talk in completely different voices.”

Text: "People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many dream about as children, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually give up these childhood dreams and choose more practical careers, such as tax lawyer or auto parts manufacturer. The idea of making a living by drawing simple doodles, like those in high school notebooks, seems unrealistic. Yet, some people do just that. 

Becoming a cartoonist is not the same for everyone, but most who succeed have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist, with a love for comic strips, contributions to school publications, and being known as ‘the kid who draws.’ I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to various companies. I was fortunate to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons about local issues. I created a few ideas, and they bought them. Within a few months, I was earning enough to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even advanced drawing skills. You just need your mind, your hand, and something to make marks with. However, if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. While the technical requirements are low, it is still a challenging job. No one should try to become a cartoonist unless they feel they cannot do anything else. It is much easier to find a regular job that pays the bills and allows time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living from your art. I have created political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also worked as a writer, caricaturist, and designer. I accept various jobs because you can learn a lot from work you may not enjoy. It also helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world.

Now, let’s talk about the business side of cartooning. There was a time when many cartoonists could find steady jobs with different newspapers and magazines. However, those days are fading. For most people today, cartooning is an entrepreneurial activity, meaning you must not only create the work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with this process, the more successful you will be. 

I have seen many cartoonists with average creativity but strong business skills do much better than those who are very talented but lack other skills. It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ circle it, and write your name and the date next to it. But realistically, it is more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If, by chance, someone steals a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it could actually be a lucky opportunity!"

Text: "Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. Among other items, I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate getting rid of even useless items, so why did I want to throw this one away? I took it to the dump and was about to leave it on a pile of trash when a young man approached me, looking confused. 'You’re not really going to throw that away, are you?' he asked. I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could take it, and I said 'Yes.' We parted ways, but in the following days and years, I felt a deep sadness about my decision.

Then, a few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it ten years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I opened this email from someone I didn’t know, a guitar dealer and restorer named Keith Rushton. He told me, 'I’ve got your electric guitar.' It had been sold and resold many times since the young man at the dump took it. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back of the guitar. He realized it was probably outdated but used my name to find me online. He eventually contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was overwhelmed with emotion. I would have given him anything he wanted, but his price was very reasonable. I had forgotten that my dad always put name-and-address stickers on my belongings, including my guitar. I could imagine how my dad would have laughed at this strange situation!

My parents had encouraged me to learn classical guitar when it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the calming sound of the instrument, which was forgiving to beginners. Unlike the violin, it didn’t sound terrible when played by someone just starting out. However, I struggled to improve, so I switched to the electric guitar and played simpler music. This was also the time of punk music, where anyone could be a rock star, even if they weren’t great musicians.

When I opened the box that Keith sent me and took out my old guitar, I suddenly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt smooth and familiar, though smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play but quickly stood up, putting a strap over my shoulder because electric guitars are meant to be played standing. My fingers instinctively knew where to go. I couldn’t have drawn a diagram for the chords I wanted to play, but my hands remembered. My middle-aged fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing down the strings to form a chord. The electric guitar is not really meant for solo playing. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I’ll need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe we can play together. Or perhaps there are others my age who have had similar experiences. We could call ourselves 'The Regainers!'"

Text: 

Recently, there has been much discussion about sleep. When I wrote my book, Insomniac, which focuses on people who struggle with sleeplessness, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and emotions. Anyone who has trouble sleeping will tell you that sleep is essential for our mental, physical, and social health. Interestingly, those who find it hardest to sleep often understand its importance the most. It is encouraging that sleep is finally receiving the attention it deserves. However, I wonder about dreams. There hasn’t been much talk about them. We often lose our dreams. When you wake up early, missing the last hour or two of sleep, you mainly lose REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep, which is when we have the most vivid dreams. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM, meaning that someone who lives to be 90 years old will spend around six or seven years dreaming. When researchers prevent people from experiencing REM sleep, they find that the next night, the amount and intensity of REM sleep increases to make up for it. This suggests that dreams serve a purpose. 

When REM sleep was discovered in 1953, many agreed with the psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research did not support this idea, and the focus shifted to the physical reasons behind dreams rather than the psychological ones. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, according to Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. 

Dreams are significant. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams much better than others. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person's interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as film is one of the most dream-like forms of human expression. However, I wondered if only creative people benefit from their dreams. Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? 

Stickgold explains that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from our past and present to create new associations. Dreams may help us discover new patterns and combinations that challenge our usual ways of thinking. For instance, Stickgold found that when people are awakened from REM sleep and asked to respond to a specific word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They tend to "ignore the obvious" and combine ideas in unexpected ways, which is a form of creativity. Personally, I find that I write better after intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one I can barely recall, seems to inspire my thoughts. On those days, words and images flow so quickly that I can hardly keep up with my typing. I don’t fully understand how this happens, but it does seem to work. 

Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and everyone needs their brains to function well. We must think creatively and flexibly as we interact with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Text: 

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London to move to a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, which has a stunning view of the sea, you see several empty frames on the walls, along with smiling photos of her two daughters. As a leading artist in the copyist art movement, who can recreate the beauty of early 20th-century impressionist paintings and 16th-century Caravaggio portraits, it seems unusual that she doesn’t keep any of her own work. “I don’t have any of my own lying around,” Susie says with a shrug. “As soon as I finish them, they go.” The reason is that Susie is in high demand. Over her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted works by many famous artists, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that art experts sometimes mistake them for the originals. While the original paintings could sell for millions at auctions, her copies sell for a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. Susie does not reveal most of her clients, even when asked, but they include galleries and private collectors. While many collectors genuinely love art, some are motivated by status. One celebrity enjoys showing off his ‘Van Gogh’ painting, which is actually a ‘Susie Ray Van Gogh’. “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s their choice.” Some collectors save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank safe and displaying Susie’s copy instead. 

Susie has always been transparent about her work. When she reproduces a classic masterpiece, she aims to make it look as authentic as possible, believing that doing it poorly would disrespect the original artist. However, she does sign her name on the back of the canvas. Passing off a copy as the real thing is illegal, and although she knows people who have profited from that, she has never been tempted. Those who create fakes often face serious consequences. Susie points out that she isn’t wealthy and has faced challenges, but her situation is more stable now, and it wouldn’t be wise to risk her reputation with collectors and artists. 

Susie didn’t always work as a copyist. After earning her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. Looking back, she sees that experience as valuable for her current work and it sparked her love for plants, even though it was hard to make ends meet. She explains that she had to be very precise and get things right on the first try. She has no regrets about that time, but she is happy to have found a more financially rewarding career. When younger artists ask her for advice, she emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights how much she has studied to master her craft. Her training allows her to create everything from plant drawings to perfect copies of 15th-century masterpieces and 20th-century abstract art, although she now focuses on French impressionists, particularly Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. 

Susie mentions that many people think modern art is simple, almost like child’s play. However, she believes that impressionists painted quickly and freely, but they were also very careful, and that combination is challenging to achieve. Given her skills, it seems strange that Susie doesn’t create her own original art. Isn’t art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She explains that her work is the result of years of training and dedication, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried creating her own pieces, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—acceptable, but not better than that. Perhaps it’s like living on plain food after enjoying meals prepared by a top chef. The key thing about Susie is that she is a perfectionist.

Text: 'During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur was deeply passionate about the sea and being the fastest on it. This obsession began in her childhood. She felt a unique connection with the boats that took her around the world; they worked together as one. When she returned to land, everyday life felt unimportant. People would ask her about the race, but she longed to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in places that had almost defeated her.

After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop round-the-world race, she showed me the small, stuffy cabin of her boat, Kingfisher. This was her home, workplace, and survival space for 94 days. She explained how carefully she planned her supplies, even counting the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was crucial for her. She proudly displayed her unappealing stock of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. Her attention to detail in keeping the boat was as impressive as her sailing skills. The boat was her entire world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, she views the world as a boat: a small, beautiful, and fragile thing with limited resources. A significant moment for her was a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she assisted in a bird survey of albatrosses. This experience made her reflect and see things differently. The many abandoned whaling stations served as a warning to her. She felt it showed how we take what we want and move on without thinking.

When I visited Ellen’s office, she was finishing a tense conference call. She explained why we must act now to protect the planet. “We no longer create coal, oil, or gas. They are valuable resources we have only once. We need to find ways to use them wisely.” Initially, her message was negative—encouraging people to use less—but she later realized there was a more positive approach. Now, she focuses on reusing materials, passionately discussing items like reusable industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, speaking with government and business leaders about our dependence on non-renewable resources. “I will never be an expert,” she admits. “But I am like a sponge, absorbing information. The current situation is something I cannot ignore. Compared to sailing, this feels less selfish. It’s about discovering how my voice can be most effective. It truly matters.”

She also founded the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that collaborates with businesses and educational institutions to inspire young people to rethink and create a sustainable future. “I do miss the adventure of being at sea,” she confesses. “It defines who I am. You feel connected to everything around you, and there’s no time to feel lonely. You focus on records, practical matters, and survival. My new message is more complex than just saying: ‘I want to be the fastest around the world.’ I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I’ve ever done.”'

Text: Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his time. He hopes to inspire other young people to explore the outdoors, especially since many spend a lot of time on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero," and climbing Everest is just part of their plan. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to have climbed the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people achieve this before turning thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of them and might complete the challenge before he finishes his teenage years.

I spoke to several experienced Everest climbers, and none thought it was a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the highest mountain in the world. They agreed that while a young climber might be physically strong, they doubted whether a teenager would have the emotional strength needed. They also questioned how a young person could have enough experience to make the right decisions and react properly in dangerous situations.

The Romeros are aware of these concerns. Paul says, "I know there is criticism, but I can't focus on it – we have so much to do. I think about the possible problems, of course. Karen and I constantly assess the risks, but we believe our experience as climbers will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is becoming very strong and mature." 

I also wonder about Jordan's motivation. Is this just an ambitious father pushing his son too far? Paul insists, "This project is not about me wanting to be famous through my son's achievements. At first, Jordan thought it was something to do later in life, but we discussed it and decided, 'Why not now?' We talk to him regularly to ensure he still wants to do it."

When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, "I just focus on achieving my goal." In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting event. The more daring the record, the more interest it attracts. This creates a challenge for Jordan. While we may feel that achievements often overshadow enjoyment, if he wants to inspire others, he must engage with the media. This means blogging, posing for photos, and giving interviews. He needs to offer something impressive, like climbing Everest. Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop mountain climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."

Text: 

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they are not listening to classical music. Many people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually don’t know who he is. I have just started a music degree, but my classmates know as little about classical music as most people our age. If someone doesn’t know who composed a piece, they probably don’t own any recordings of it. This situation must be disappointing for classical music lovers. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music events, and the average classical recording sells only about 300 copies. I find that hard to believe. 

So, why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games for this decline, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who enjoy classical concerts, but they are not the majority. Even though I play in an orchestra, I’m not a big fan of classical music. I enjoy many styles, but my classical music listening is probably close to that 3% figure.

Why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, can be challenging for us. We prefer fast conversations, quick actions, and rapid thoughts. Experts say we struggle to pay attention for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Additionally, pop music often deals with topics that interest teenagers, while classical music usually does not. 

The way we listen to music has also changed. In the past, families would gather to play music together, and playing an instrument was highly valued. Now, we can find any music we want online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that audiences at classical concerts have increased recently. Maybe, but I doubt many of those new attendees are teenagers. In my orchestra, we perform classical music in various places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I don’t know why more people are drawn to classical concerts as they age, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might want to avoid it.

Some people blame schools for teenagers’ lack of interest in classical music, but many students are eager to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they perform, but it’s not their preferred music outside of that. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we usually choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham stepped out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you regret I came here,” she said to the school, with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie wouldn’t have minded if she had. Her mother understood how Bonnie felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was an unusual school, with buildings scattered among the trees on a hillside; it was quite confusing at first. Then she noticed the signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved through the trees. “I wish you’d walk next to me instead of behind me like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t seem to expect Bonnie to do so. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll be kicked out soon anyway, so why not get it over with?” She left the building and went towards the riding centre, following the sign. 

There was a charming old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one there. She approached the horses with a sense of respect. The horses were well cared for, and she noticed that immediately. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, carefully observing each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. Then she saw the next horse and stopped. “But aren’t you the best of the bunch!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, which Bonnie liked. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…” Above the stall was his name: Maverick. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. It can’t be far.” 

Bonnie was thrilled to find that the room with the riding equipment was unlocked. As she focused on putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she climbed onto the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in control of everything around her. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said with admiration. “I’m serious, I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him into a walk, then a trot. “If I stay here, I think we could be great friends,” she said. She rode around the paddock, feeling exhilarated as a gentle breeze brushed against her cheek. She sensed that Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he would jump well.

Text: 'I have met Cody Simpson before and have always admired his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released many successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up performing in front of thousands of fans? “I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven,” Cody recalls, explaining how it all started. “But I was swimming and surfing every day. Those activities were more important to me back then; I had a full life and many things to do. When I was 13 and in high school, I posted a few videos online.” These videos changed everything. He began by sharing a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, asking for more videos. Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share them. The response was overwhelming. Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with top coaches and focused on improving his skills. But then record labels showed interest, and he faced a difficult choice: stay in Australia and continue swimming, or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the leap. “It was very hard for me – especially at such a young age – to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?” He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the States. “It surprised most people. I’m the quiet kid,” he says, remembering their shocked faces. “I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to stay that way in this crazy industry.” So Cody packed his bags and traveled halfway around the world with his family, giving up one dream to pursue another. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and is not directly involved in his career, they support him from behind the scenes. Cody believes it’s important to have a close circle of good people around you to keep you grounded. Of course, everyone has moments of doubt. “Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How does my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight years old, and he’s traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,” Cody admits. “I worry about how that affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.” Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big opportunity, even when it feels a bit scary. “It all happened so quickly and unexpectedly,” Cody says. “Now, I’m visiting countries I never thought I would see and performing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s something many people dream of achieving. But I know it won’t last forever.”

Text: 

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the river ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting them into place. Last week, I had worked long hours with most of the town’s adults, showing that I could handle the job. My grandfather, however, didn’t seem to notice. 

With one hand still on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of dark water created by the release pipe from the wood processing factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on either side, and solid ice further downstream. As I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. I didn’t recognize him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from an expedition in South America. This chain is more special to me than having a famous grandfather, and only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that journey, which I keep under my pillow and read before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen. 

“Good morning, Rex,” my mom smiled as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training session. Be careful.” 

“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his bedroom. 

“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was obvious from my wetsuit, and he had seen me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa can be difficult, and it’s been harder for me to ignore his temper lately. 

“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His harsh words hit me hard for a moment. But I took a deep breath and counted to three. He walked away and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came in with a sympathetic smile. 

“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 

“...not himself right now,” I finished for her. I held back from saying he had always been like this. Like my mom, I try to be understanding. When I was a child, he was my hero, especially when he showed me photos of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang framed on his bedroom wall, along with his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own face in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. 

My mom smiled. “At least he’s coming out of his bedroom more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even on these cold days!” 

I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It’ll be warmer in South America,” I said. “If I find sponsors for my expedition.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried towards the boathouse.

Text: Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her into the study, where she saw an unframed painting on the table. It was clearly one of Grandpa's works, but it looked different and was obviously unfinished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." 

Jess looked closely at the painting. A river took up most of the scene; it was not a river she recognized, perhaps just a fantasy river. The painting was strange and beautiful in a haunting way. The riverbank was barely visible, just a hint of green that drew the eye into the pale waters, leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, she felt captivated, thinking about autumn coming after a long summer.

Mum spoke again. "It has a name." There was something in her voice that showed her excitement, even though she tried to sound casual. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings; he just painted them and let others interpret them. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: "River Boy." The words felt strangely significant to her, but she couldn't explain why. 

There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it? For him to be so specific. But he hasn't finished it yet, so maybe he will add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess; she knew what Grandpa would say. "He told you it's not the artist's job to explain a painting because each one has its own life and language, just like a poem. We either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to every idiot..." "Ignoramus, he said." "...every ignoramus what it means. If artists had to explain their work to everyone, they would never get anything done. And he said..." Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him." 

"Inspire?" Jess asked. "Someone who motivates an artist." She knew the meaning. Grandpa often used the word when she watched him paint, but he usually meant that the muse wasn't helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a tough part to work on. He never suggested that the muse was related to her. In fact, she thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

Text: 

This morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally gone into the carpet and made a big hole. I’m not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn’t wake up thinking, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the moment, as things often do. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This happens to me quite often. 

What I was really trying to do was find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and old-fashioned ladies. Now, I keep my collection of shells and fossils there. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, and I was excited when she gave it to me! 

The problem is, it is a corner cabinet, which means it has to fit in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it’s the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is for Mum and Dad; the back one is my sister Angela’s; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and the tiny one, like a broom cupboard, is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. When Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I’ll be stuck in my small room for a long time. 

I don’t really mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. Then I thought, if I can’t cut anything off the cabinet, why not cut a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to “think outside the box.” And that’s exactly what I was doing!

Text: 'The novel ‘The Borrowers’ tells the story of a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They "borrow" items from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV adaptation of this novel, I knew it would be challenging to meet people’s expectations. Fans of the book have strong opinions about how it should be portrayed. I used the original illustrations from the book as a guide because I wanted to avoid criticism for getting it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, not from the humans', which made filming more complicated.

A key aspect was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on their borrowing adventures, we had to position the camera ten times further away than usual. To capture the Borrowers' perspective, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from a height of no more than 15 centimeters. They went through many pairs of jeans! We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. 

One major challenge was creating realistic shadows when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized surroundings. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, the famous US director George Lucas called to ask how we achieved it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floor, filled with oversized objects to make the actors appear small. It was wonderfully surreal. I remember asking them to carry giant scissors, and they really embraced the idea. The coins we used were larger than dinner plates and hard to lift, which often made the crew laugh, causing us to stop filming.

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to be pushed down a tunnel with hoses, and they found it so scary that they didn’t need to act. It was also important to me to get the costumes right, which has been a struggle for other directors. I had the costumes made from heavy canvas so they would stick out like dolls' clothes. This made it very difficult for the lead actress to move; she couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal fabric would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail with the costumes!

Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was challenging for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of each scene to show how they should look, and by the end, I had created 2,000 drawings. They weren’t perfect, but they were helpful. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly; I once filmed an entire scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But in the end, everything came together, and I believe the series successfully captured the magic of the books.'

Text: 'Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, expecting to see journalists, but there aren’t any. I wonder how long it will take for the chaos to start. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones who ask for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to escape my old life of touring and tutors. While the rest of the band is renting here for recording, we are staying for good. I insisted on coming to this school because I want to meet regular kids. How about a kid whose mom works in an office or a dad who mows lawns? That would be so cool. 

I walk into the school’s main office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I say to the school secretary. “Name?” she asks, looking unfriendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary seems confused. “Oh,” she says and types “McGraw” on her keyboard. That’s one good thing; few people recognize my last name because my dad uses a stage name. “What grade?” “Eleventh.” “One moment, it’s printing,” the secretary says. Then she rips the sheet and hands it to me. English Literature, first period. Great, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look foolish searching for my classes. 

When I reach the door, I hear the teacher taking attendance. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my very normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with tan embroidered flowers. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses in the attendance. “Desert... McGraw?” she says carefully. “Here.” The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and eventually gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read this year, she actually lets us socialize! All teachers should understand how important this is. 

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have a few options. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” Essence? I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a recording studio so close to the sand? “My dad had to relocate,” I tell her. Yes, lies work better. “What does he do?” she asks. Oh, whatever. Everyone will find out eventually. But at least I can pretend to be normal for a while. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with the zipper on my backpack. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” And she doesn’t seem to care much. Excellent.'

Text: 

Today, American teenage girls are expected to be Student Council presidents, have part-time jobs, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is the reality for teenagers now. Both boys and girls cannot just attend school and remain unnoticed; being average is no longer enough. Mediocrity is seen as unacceptable, and lacking ambition is viewed as laziness. Teenager Kristen Loose points out that many adults forget the pressure teenagers face today. They deal with heavy homework loads, tests, extracurricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to maintain a social life.

Despite these pressures being common, negative stereotypes about teenagers still exist, often spread by the media. These stereotypes include being lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers may fit these descriptions, many believe it is unfair to label an entire generation this way. Loose argues that people often think teenagers spend most of their time glued to screens. She acknowledges that she keeps her cellphone close, but not for trivial reasons. For her, it is a tool that helps make life easier for herself and those around her. 

Today, students are expected to have constant access to information and be reachable at all times, which can create the impression of cellphone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere. Instead of just listening to music on the way to school, they might be listening to language lessons. Schoolwork and other responsibilities now demand attention around the clock, adding to the stress of already busy teenagers. Many start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often finish after midnight, balancing school, activities, family duties, and homework. They often get less than the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. A survey by the US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of American teenagers get enough sleep, and 28 percent admitted to falling asleep in school at least once a week due to lack of sleep.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen believes that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, this is not much. Olsen rarely spends this time on social media or watching TV; instead, she dedicates it to volunteer work. She feels that many people think teenagers are self-centered and only care about their own interests. However, Olsen says her favorite part of the week is volunteering. She enjoys helping others and looks forward to making a positive impact in her school and community.

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers may change, but they will continue to challenge these views and contribute positively to the world. There will always be new generations of students making a difference before they even finish school.
