The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In recent years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This ongoing science project is both an astronomy experiment and an outdoor adventure, which is likely why teenagers join. I visited them one weekend in late spring. They were preparing to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a bright trail of light.

As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside the lunch box were a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer to check temperature changes during the ascent. Two GPS trackers were placed on the outside to help them find it later. A gas tank, donated by a supporter from a nearby state, was used to inflate the balloon, which slowly grew to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour round trip to get the gas tank. “I didn’t really mind,” he said. For kids in this club, that’s just part of the experience.

Finally, it was time for lift-off. “Five, four, three, two, one,” they counted down, and the balloon began to rise. Some of the teenagers ran to track its path with powerful flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There was a quiet moment filled with wonder as the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside, looking at a sky so clear that it was hard to believe they were only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with around 4 million people. I saw a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. “We’re the only ones talking,” said one girl quietly. “I know,” whispered another. Suddenly, a meteor shot across the sky.

As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, causing it to expand until it was almost the size of a house. Then it popped with a loud bang. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Retrieving it was not easy, but that was part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. “Recoveries are a big part of the program,” said the group’s leader, noting they had lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. “Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.”

On this occasion, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. “These students are familiar with the Eastern Sierra,” their leader explained. “What seems wild and dangerous to some is just a normal part of life for others.” In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, near a waterfall. The camera did not capture any shooting stars. While this was a bit disappointing, it provided a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they might behave above mountains. It was also another adventure story to share with anyone who asked.

Chloe Morgan admits that she was not very interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she turned fifteen. Her interest began by chance when her younger brother was fascinated by dinosaurs, a phase many children go through. Although she initially dismissed his interest, she helped him with a science project and discovered an article about recent findings in Palaeontology that amazed her. She realized that this was a field she wanted to pursue.

I asked Chloe what support she received, as Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people at that time. She recalled meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already well-known despite his youth. Chloe felt nervous at first, worried that he might see her as just an annoying kid. However, she felt more comfortable when he showed patience and listened to her questions.

I brought up how palaeontologists are portrayed in movies and TV shows. Chloe expressed her frustration, noting that films like Jurassic Park, which feature dinosaurs created with special effects, have increased public interest in dinosaurs but not necessarily in Palaeontology itself. She feels that palaeontologists are often shown as either eccentric geniuses or socially awkward individuals, which does not reflect the reality of their work.

Chloe explained that her job is very diverse. She spends time digging for dinosaur bones, working in laboratories to analyze fossils, and writing scientific papers. Although not always required, she also believes in the importance of communicating scientific findings to the public. She wants to help young people understand science better, as discussing dinosaurs can inspire their interest in the natural world and other scientific fields.

The recent TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs gave Chloe a chance to influence how dinosaurs are shown on screen. She noted that the producers were knowledgeable, and her role was mainly to ensure accuracy, such as confirming that the dinosaurs depicted lived during the same time period. The documentary attracted viewers of all ages because it presented dinosaurs in a way that was much more realistic than in movies like Jurassic Park.

When I asked Chloe why dinosaurs continue to captivate us and remain a focus of research, she suggested that they appeal to our natural curiosity and desire for exploration. Dinosaurs remind us that there is still much to discover in our world, and Palaeontology offers a unique way to explore the past.

Text: "I want to make one thing clear: when you are traveling by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know that you are not 'there yet,' even if you keep asking, 'Are we there yet?' The truth is, once you arrive, it’s not 'there' anymore; it’s 'here.' So if you think you might be 'there' already, you should be asking, 'Are we here yet?' I’m sure no one wishes to be 'there yet' more than the parents who hear that question repeatedly on long car trips. 

Think about it. Wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with no responsibilities? You could watch DVDs you’ve never seen, listen to music, or do puzzles you’ve had for a long time, while enjoying the beautiful views outside. Meanwhile, your parent in the front seat, with a map, is there to hand out juice boxes and cookies, change the radio station, and keep everything running smoothly. 

But then, someone in the car does something annoying—usually my younger brother, Tim. For example, he might put his foot on my side of the seat. I can’t let that happen, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, he’s leaning over into my space, and a fight starts. The driver and the other parent have to reach back to separate us while the car swerves. They tell Tim to stay in his own seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a bit, and we continue to see the amazing scenery.

Later, when I try to read, I feel a draft on my arm. The window isn’t open, so where is it coming from? Tim is next to me, quietly blowing his breath in my direction. He’s not touching me, so he thinks he’s being clever. I get angry, and Tim gets yelled at again. The chaos settles down for now.

Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle us in the back seat. When we ask, 'Are we there yet?' he often replies, 'Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.' But we are still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour. Then he says, 'Oh, maybe we’re not there yet.' This keeps us quiet for a while. 

You can tell when you finally arrive because the adults jump out of the car and move as far away from us as possible after all those hours. So remember: if your parents are still close enough to answer your question, the answer is: no, you are not there yet."

Text: John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. The owners hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains their motivation: “There is so much technology today. Everyone is busy with their phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together in a way that doesn’t involve screens. It’s natural for people to connect and communicate with each other.”

The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games often have gentle themes, like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged until the end, so no one feels left out. This idea was improved in ‘co-operative’ games, where all players work together to win or lose as a team, encouraging more social interaction. One popular co-operative game is Pandemic, designed by North American Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players must work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, based on the famous book. He recalls, “When I played that with friends, we felt scared and excited. In the end, everyone felt good, whether they won or lost. I wanted to create something similar.”

Leacock’s love for board games started when he was a child. He says, “Games were my favorite birthday gift, but I often felt disappointed after playing them.” With help from his uncle, he would redesign games to make them better. Pandemic became a huge success, and its follow-up game advanced game design even further. Leacock explains, “It has a lot of storytelling. It’s like a video game where you develop characters, learn new rules, and the story changes as you play.”

Interestingly, the growth of the video game industry has helped the popularity of modern board games. Many people now play games on their smartphones, making them more open to playing board games. Ben Hogg, who works for a leading games company, says, “Everyone plays mobile games now. Most people with smartphones have at least one game they enjoy.”

For a while, video games allowed some social interaction, like playing together at arcades or on the couch. However, as multiplayer games moved online, players became physically distant from each other. This led some people to seek out ways to play games with others in person again. As seen in John and Zuzi's busy café, tabletop gaming has become more than just entertainment. In our increasingly online world, games are now something to be shared directly and physically, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows that endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many false starts. He mentions that his mother was an "amazing singer" who encouraged him to play the guitar. The only radio station he listened to at home was a local one for middle-aged people, which influenced his musical taste as he grew up. He was 12 years old when he first heard a contemporary song. Around the same time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the music room at school learning songs on the piano. He said, "With tennis, I was at a high level, but it was not what I wanted to do for my life. It was just too much hard work." At 17, he left school to pursue a career as a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but did not share his passion for performing. Jamie recalls, "I went to my parents and broke down. I told them this is what I wanted to do, that I had been writing lyrics in economics lessons and playing the piano every day while others were outside." His father gave him 18 months to succeed; if he didn’t, he would need to find a job. After several near misses with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 based on one song. However, record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend. Eventually, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. Fame and fortune did not come easily. He said, "In my artist career, I feel like I’ve been in the wrong place at the wrong time. But as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time." Writing for other artists is where he truly found success. He believes he is one of the main writers that UK labels turn to for new artists. He helps launch their careers and sometimes has to explain that aiming for chart success is not something to be ashamed of. He asks artists, "Why don’t you want to? Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?" He emphasizes that they should aim to create something amazing that will also sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone in pop music speak openly about wanting to write big hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he simply knows he wants to write number one songs and has the talent to do it. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his goals. He says, "When I go into the studio with someone, we need to aim for global success and write the best music of next year. It’s not just about what’s cool; we want to create classic modern pop songs."

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very popular online, but many people, like me, may not know him if they don’t watch online videos of bike stunts. He is known as a ‘street trials cyclist.’ This means he jumps from difficult places, like roofs or walls, to land safely in other challenging spots. These stunts are recorded and shared online.

On the day I interview him, we meet at a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local kids all know who he is, and several older people come to greet him, calling him ‘an absolute legend.’ After watching him perform, I agree with them. I came with some doubts, but I am impressed by his bravery, creativity, and willingness to take risks. Before each stunt, he explains what he plans to do, and sometimes I can’t believe he will succeed. When I compliment him after his performance, he seems uninterested and a bit down.

Even though he is famous online, Tony says he does not enjoy being a celebrity. He finds the social side of fame difficult. He understands the importance of connecting with fans, but he prefers to focus on doing stunts rather than talking about them. This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and the small cameras that capture his stunts. He says, “This technology allows people like me to earn a living.” However, he feels that many people are too focused on recording themselves or looking at screens, and he does not fully agree with that.

Tony makes a good living from his videos, which is different from how it used to be for people in similar sports. After many years of interviewing top athletes, I have learned that two key factors help a child become a top competitor: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These traits can be more important than talent and help a person keep going despite failures. In risky sports, it is especially important to have mental strength. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on what he considered easy but new challenges. He just got back up and kept trying until he succeeded.

Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some people think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He responds, “Those who criticize me may be worried, but they don’t understand. They probably have never ridden a trials bike and don’t know much about the sport. They don’t realize that I get advice from experts to reduce risks.” In reality, Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He explains, “People are different. Some never feel scared, and they shouldn’t be doing these sports. It’s important to recognize the dangers. The rest of us can be divided into those who can overcome fear and those who cannot. I belong to the group that feels fear but finds a way to move past it. I am not addicted to risk; I spend a lot of time planning and preparing. Sometimes, I ride around for a while to get in the right mindset before trying a new stunt. I know I must stay calm just before I jump. If I fully commit, then I am fine.”

Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on many dangerous challenges for charity, such as running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net; she only had a belt around her waist connected to another wire above her. To help her balance and avoid falling, she used a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Although she had some circus skills, she found that high-wire walking was very different. “The training was a shock,” Helen said. “I didn’t realize how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and then another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could keep going if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I got nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!” On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. “That was the scariest thing I’ve done,” she said afterward. “I’m glad it’s over!” Despite this experience, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by skiing, kiting, and biking.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. He had previously written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motorsport and worked building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and also used it for a holiday in Amsterdam. He said, “That trip opened my eyes. I decided to see the world by bike.” Jeff wanted a unique touring bike and decided to build one himself. He thought a penny farthing would be the most interesting choice, so he visited a museum to learn how they were made. After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, which ended due to a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries across four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. He met cyclists who could ride up mountains, but he never regretted choosing the penny farthing. The further he traveled from home, the more people were amazed by his bike. His toughest experience was having to drink dirty water from a stream, which caused him a serious fever. He spent ten days in a hostel without medicine and had no money for a hospital or to return home. Despite these challenges, Jeff now says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”

I work at a university in the United States, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have recently started using a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’, which helps us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about the black duck population because their numbers have decreased significantly, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. While we have plenty of information about their activities during the day, we lack knowledge about their nighttime behavior due to the absence of proper equipment. This new scope will provide clear images, even on nights without a moon, allowing us to learn more and make informed decisions about protecting their habitat.

Our work is challenging. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in various locations, and I have had to take a boat to some sites to record every duck I observe. The weather has been a factor; some nights are mild, but many are rainy. It is so quiet that I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one workday because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. Despite the difficulties, I enjoy the challenge, especially when I think about the summer ahead, which will involve long hours in a laboratory analyzing our findings together. Being indoors will be tough, but it is necessary. I wouldn’t change this experience for anything!

Text: "When I tell people about my job, they often find it hard to believe it exists. But I’m serious! I spend my workdays tasting chocolate! Tasting is a crucial part of ensuring that customers receive high-quality chocolate bars from my company. Each week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate from our factory, and I need to check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, to select the best ones for our chocolate. 

Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I create, and I share samples with my colleagues! My kitchen is filled with machines and ingredients, and it’s great to have a private space to work in during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I work in our food lab, and other times I travel abroad to buy raw materials, which can be challenging since I have a young family. However, I enjoy the variety and lack of routine in my job, although I think the chocolate itself is the best part! 

People often ask me if I ever get bored of chocolate. I’ve worked with it for a long time, and I’ve never felt tired of eating it. In fact, I often go home and enjoy more chocolate in the evening!"

Text: 'Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a center that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it includes many skills, such as juggling, throwing and catching objects like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves flying through the air in front of an amazed audience. 

During the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can attend some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, “For a career in the circus, performers need to avoid doing the same thing repeatedly – it’s essential to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great aspect is the friendships formed with other performers and the opportunity to learn from them. Staying fit is also very important – circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is crucial, but the best performers are those who are determined to succeed, have creativity, and continuously work on improving their skills. 

People often think that circus performers are likely to get injured or that they only work for a short time each year. However, the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only perform while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also includes business planning. Many former students have started their own businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, though, that it’s not a profession for making a lot of money! “The work usually does not provide a regular salary. It’s also competitive – but a lot of fun!”'

Text: 'You may not know her name or face, but you have likely heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer, someone who supports the lead singer by singing in the background. Many people believe that backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers, but that is not true – they often have to be even better. People like Mariam are the true stars of the music industry! 

“What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing,” she says. “It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes, it might even be a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never complain; I just get on with the job!”

“Excellent musical skills are essential for my work, along with the ability to learn quickly. There is often no written music to follow. I will never forget my first experience recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, along with an orchestra. I was scared because I knew that if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are already long enough.”

“One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers do not always know which musical range works best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it.”

Text: "Starting with only basic knowledge of fashion, Julie Deane built a successful business selling 'satchels' – traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular among many celebrities. Before deciding on satchels, Julie considered various business ideas, from cake decorating to party planning, instead of just going with her first thought. Once she made her choice, not everyone supported her. Julie recalls, 'Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced.' She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children's storybooks. Although Julie was not familiar with fashion blogs, they played a key role in her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel a week. To generate interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her products grew, along with the speed at which her company produced the satchels. Julie now enjoys waiting to see which celebrity will be seen with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online advertising, she uses the online community for ideas on new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied Julie’s design to sell similar bags. As a result, she now ensures she has confidence in her production team, just as she does in her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices – people enjoy working there. There is now a new factory, and while the buildings are important, it is the team that makes it a special place."

Text: 'When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents allowed her and her brother Jamie to choose how they spent their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach believed she had the potential to become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard for her to balance training with her schoolwork. As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and began competing. Vicky found this exciting and decided to try cycling too. She later said it was the best choice she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and performing well. The track was close to her school, so attending training sessions after school was easy for her. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. When she turned 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky explained, ‘For years, I enjoyed winning, but I started to feel tired of it all – when the excitement fades, it loses its meaning. Fortunately, I found a new career.’ Vicky began working for a charity called CycleZone. ‘We help young people who have never enjoyed sports,’ she says. ‘Our first step is to teach them how to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does important work, bringing young people together to form a community.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their efforts. Vicky comments, ‘Some people doubt that celebrity support is always beneficial for a charity. They argue that celebrities may be more interested in their own image, which can distract from the charity's real work. However, if famous singers and actors can help, I believe they should.’

Text: 'Ana Ronson is a singer-songwriter from Ireland. Even though her parents were not musicians, music was always present in her home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of an audience was at school, and she was so nervous that her teacher had to take her off the stage. This teacher suggested that she join the school theatre club to help her gain confidence. After participating in the club for some time, she happily sang with 50 other students at a concert at the end of the term. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days and enjoyed it so much that she signed up for a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Although she was the youngest student, she knew more about music than many of the others. However, Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her, which inspired her to write the song Something to Say about her frustration. She shared this song online, and it became very popular. She was thrilled when people commented that they loved it and found new meanings in it each time they listened. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled from the other side of Ireland to invite her to join his company. At first, Ana was unsure because she did not know much about Isotope and did not want anyone telling her what to sing. However, Joss convinced her that this would not happen, and soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and it was a fantastic evening. Ana prefers to write songs about difficult times rather than happy moments, as she feels she has more to express then. One of her favorite songs is Decision, which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it affected him. While she hopes her fans will enjoy her music, her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.'

Text: 'Last year, I went on an incredible trip – a guided boat tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and wanted to write articles about the journey. He loves boats, which is not something I share. However, I had always dreamed of visiting this area since I saw it on TV as a child, especially because it was where our great-grandparents lived before moving to Europe. I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally said yes! 

A few days before our departure, there were storms in the area we were visiting. Fortunately, the weather forecast for our trip was calm seas. I was busy with work and didn’t have much time to prepare, but Harry assured me he would handle everything, so I stopped worrying. 

After arriving in Canada, we met the group, packed our supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide mentioned that very few people live along that coast, and indeed, the only other creatures we saw that first morning were dolphins and birds. We could see islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water. 

We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of colorful fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was wonderful to forget about how fast or slow the day was going. We never forgot lunch or dinner, which we all prepared together over campfires. When we finally fell asleep on the boats each night, even though the beds were hard, it felt like a stress-free life! 

When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew if I stayed, I would miss my family and friends. I was also excited to share our adventures with everyone at home!'

Text: "My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a child, I watched many of his games. You might think that this would make me love basketball, but it actually did the opposite. I enjoyed telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I often brought a book to read instead of watching the games.

When I started secondary school, I was still two years away from being a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. Because of my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I liked the training sessions, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, my teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After some time, I agreed to play, and a few weeks later, I found myself in a game against another school. My parents watching made me more nervous, but it turned out fine!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did very well, even joining an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trained Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy being away from my parents at first. At home, I hadn’t spent much time with friends because of all the training, so that part wasn’t too different for me. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight to match my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it."

Text: "Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college and needed a part-time job because my course was quite expensive. After thinking about different options, I decided to train as a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. I was surprised by how much I enjoyed giving tours. I saw the city I had lived in my whole life from the perspective of tourists, and it felt like a new experience each time! After I finished my studies, I chose to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but when I researched what was required, I learned that to get a license as a full-time tour guide, I needed to know much more than I had learned so far. All Chicago guides must answer many questions about the city, including local architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I earned my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent tour guide. 

Tour guiding is not just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds. There are many other important skills. You need to be entertaining and tell interesting stories, and most importantly, you must be able to adapt to changing situations. For example, if a place you planned to visit is closed or if the route changes, you need to handle it well. Tourists do not want to hear about problems or feel like they are missing out; they just want to enjoy a well-organized tour. I must ensure that visitors are happy with my tours, as negative reviews online can harm my business. Like most tour guides, I understand that good reviews are very important because they attract more customers. That is why making tours enjoyable and stress-free is essential. I believe that the enthusiasm and energy I bring to my job lead to positive reviews, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago."

Text: "My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I traveled to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Although she is five years younger than me, we have a good relationship. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary, a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was unsure if we would connect with the other volunteers because they were all older than us. We were also nervous since it was our first experience doing something like this. However, we ended up having a great time. 

One of our main tasks at the sanctuary was to gather food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of our day. Josie found it challenging, but seeing the elephants enjoy their meals made it worthwhile for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with large brushes and soap. I found this very enjoyable, even though I ended up wetter than the elephants!

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants into the forest where they would spend the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a small bedroom because she didn’t want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we were prepared for that. The meals were delicious and did not include meat, which we both do not like. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff would spend the evenings talking and playing games.

Now that we are back in the UK, Josie does not often mention Thailand. However, if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. I am not sure if she is being completely honest. I think she might feel a bit frustrated with herself for not fully enjoying her time there because she missed her friends too much. But when she reflects on the experience, she realizes how fortunate she was to go. Maybe she will return one day – I definitely will!"

Text: "My name is Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers not only to individuals for gifts or home decoration but also to various businesses. Hotels and offices often use flowers in their reception areas, and we sometimes provide flowers for photo shoots for companies' advertisements. Once, I even decorated a castle for a wedding, which was a lot of work, but I felt very proud of the result.

My day begins at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep at that time, and my friends think I’m a bit crazy, but I love what I do. It can be quite cold and dark, but I don’t let that bother me. The flower market is amazing, filled with flowers from around the world. The beautiful sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were buying for myself, I would probably choose only pink flowers, as that is my favorite color. However, I have to remember that my preferences may not match what my customers want. Not all flowers are available throughout the year, which can make it difficult to meet their requests.

I don’t enjoy negotiating prices with the flower sellers, but it is part of my job. Flowers can be expensive, so I try to get the best price I can. Once I return to the shop, we review customer orders and prepare vases with the flowers I bought. Then, we create flower arrangements and calculate the costs of the orders. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes need to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some might think this is too much effort, but I enjoy finding the best combinations of flowers for the budget someone has. That’s what selling is about, and I wouldn’t want to do anything else!"

Text: "My city has a modern cinema that shows the latest films and many children's movies on weekends. It is close to my home, but a year ago, I realized I wanted something more – the chance to discuss a film in detail with others after watching it. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema for our screenings. Instead, we choose a different location in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which created a great atmosphere for the film, and it was fantastic! Some places we use are free because the owners sell snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We are happy to cover our costs without trying to make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets easier, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We can track ticket sales online, so we no longer worry about empty seats! There is always a lot to do, but when people of all ages tell us how much they enjoyed the experience at the end, it feels wonderful. Our website has been very helpful, and we are now connected with other film clubs across the country. We have visited them to see how they operate, but it is always nice to return to our own club! We also started a blog because we know most people look online for film information instead of reading local reviews. We have tried putting up posters in cafés, but nothing is as effective as word of mouth – people telling their friends about us. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film; last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed."

Taking photographs was always my favorite activity as a child. When I turned 15, I wanted to take my hobby further, so I decided to start a special project: I would take one photograph every day for a whole year. Many other young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea, so I began. After a few weeks, I decided to share my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show others my work. I was surprised to find that many people appreciated my unique perspective.

I enjoyed photographing a variety of subjects, but then someone suggested that my project would be even better if all my photos had a common theme. I agreed and started focusing on nature, especially birds and the sky. Most of my photos were in black and white, which was different from what many other young photographers were doing, as they preferred color. This made me doubt my project at times, and I almost gave up. However, I learned to trust my feelings and became more confident in my style and choices.

One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She informed me about a national photography competition for my age group, so I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget the moment when the judges announced that I had won first prize. I was incredibly happy because my project meant so much to me. It was the first time I realized that my photography might be good enough for a professional career. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I have never regretted my choice of career.

Text: "I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try new activities like camping, sailing, and public speaking. In the NYC, you can participate in various activities that help you grow and learn. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called ‘leaders’. When you complete each level, you receive a certificate. 

When I first joined, my leader suggested that I help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was unsure about this because I had joined that same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own groups, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to accept the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. 

Soon, I found myself wanting to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became much more important to me than just getting the certificate. After I completed the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to continue volunteering at the club because I had formed good relationships with the children. Now, I spend about four hours a week there, and I always look forward to it. 

Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I have decided that after I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. I had never thought about my future job or youth work before starting at the club. This experience has been my favorite part of the NYC, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I now have several NYC certificates, including one for camping!"

Text: "I was born in Denver, USA, and I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort about two hours from Denver. The slope looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was too young to ask him if I could start, but he loved the sport and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and eventually, I did well. After that first experience, I quickly grew to love snowboarding and improved my skills. I began competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my passion for participating and winning has only grown stronger over the years, which motivates me to work harder. I like not having a strict plan, and sometimes this works out well, like when I became the first female to score a perfect 100 in a local competition. I didn’t think I would attempt the jumps that earned me that score until I actually started. That achievement boosted my confidence in my abilities. 

In the summer, I focus on training and my studies when there is no snow. I train every day, but I enjoy not having to follow a strict diet like I do in winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends during this time. It helps me cope with not being able to do what I love and what I’m good at. I need to think about my future carefully. Snowboarding is a big part of my life now, but I believe it’s important to have another option in case I don’t succeed as a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I am considering whether becoming a doctor is a possibility, depending on whether my active lifestyle allows me to study for a college degree. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever."

Text: "When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I never thought about the future. For example, I didn’t know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I thought I should have one too. My parents said I could only get it if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I am very grateful to my parents for making me do that – it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn’t enjoy it much, so my parents suggested I start my own small business. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try that. I never thought I would find it so easy, as it looked complicated when I watched my mum. My friends thought it sounded boring, but I was excited about it. My mum showed me that I could create something nice at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewellery to my friends and family as soon as I finished making them. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. Even though I was happy they bought them, I still needed to be sure they were good enough for other people. The only way to find out was to rent a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my items to take home. Soon, we started getting calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many employees, but we were just two people at a market stall! That was when I realized it could work, and it was time to take the next step – creating a website. Since then, I’ve made thousands of pounds from my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It has been a lot of fun so far."

Text: 'When Janine Stuart was just 13 years old, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. The book is partly based on Janine’s own life. In an interview, Janine explained, “Because of my father’s job, my family moved around a lot, so I learned how to make new friends. I know what it’s like to be the only new student in a class, and that helped me write about how the main character, Amelia, adjusts to a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I’m an only child, I had to use my imagination to describe that.” 

Janine started writing her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to spend her time this way. The year before, she had entered a short story competition on a young writers’ website and won first prize. This is why, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were eager to read it. They loved the book, and a year later, it was available in bookstores. 

One review of Being Amelia notes that, despite the cheerful pictures of teenagers on the cover, the characters face real challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer mentions that even though Janine is still very young and her novel isn’t very long, she has shown that she is a better writer than many bestselling authors. Janine is still adjusting to her fame: “At first, I would hide when people recognized me in the street, but now it’s fine. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, I just need to spend time with my friends, and I’ll soon have something interesting to write about!”'

Text: "My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved into a castle on a small island. This happened because my father was invited to manage the castle. He works for an organization that cares for historical buildings and keeps them open to the public. He was excited about this opportunity, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree that he should accept the job. We were worried about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our cozy home across the water, and there was no school nearby. However, once we moved, we quickly adapted to island life. The castle is not particularly beautiful, but our apartment there is comfortable. 

In the summer, the island feels very lively because many visitors come, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we mostly see the other families who live on the island, but there are not as many teenagers as I had hoped. The adults support each other and help with repairs, which often requires a lot of hard work. 

The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I looked forward to the stormy days when there are big waves, but the ferries do not run then! I also learned that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I will miss the last ferry home, which is stressful. So, when my schoolmates visit, I always tell them to hurry! 

Despite these challenges, we often enjoy amazing views, especially when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it is so foggy that you cannot see anything, but within hours, it can be bright and sunny again. This still feels incredible, even after living here for a while. Of course, we do experience terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to withstand them. But then I remind myself that it has been here for centuries and is still standing!"

I live in a house surrounded by beautiful countryside in Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals, and six years ago, I started a new hobby: birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural habitat. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to identify different species and find the best spots to see them. It was incredible, and after returning home, I joined a local birdwatchers’ club for young people. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I am close to achieving that. During family holidays abroad, I have had the chance to see birds from other countries as well. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities so I can add new birds to my list! I have been to Egypt, and last summer we traveled to South America, where I thought I would see my 200th species. I was not too disappointed when it didn’t happen, as I have learned that patience is important in this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers found it interesting and commented positively. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I didn’t feel nervous until just before they introduced me and I walked onto the stage. I knew I would remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I had prepared well and they really enjoyed it. I might even do another presentation next year! I am fortunate to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not consider becoming birdwatchers, but there are actually many birds to see, especially in areas with lots of greenery. I also believe that birdwatching clubs should work to attract more young people to this hobby. Everyone should connect with nature, regardless of their age, and it doesn’t have to be expensive.

Text: "I began playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and after some time, I became a decent player. However, my family knew that I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they probably thought I would do the same with football. But that never happened. In fact, I started dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one of the referees saw that I was a talented player, so he asked the manager of a professional women's club to watch me. After that, she invited me to join her club. I was surprised at first – I didn’t know that young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager was impressed, and I began regular training with a big club when I was just 13. After that, I improved a lot. Still, some people doubted I would ever become a star player, which made me a bit sad. But the coach encouraged me to be myself and to believe in my abilities – he even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I expected! I ran harder than ever because I didn’t want to let the other players down. Then, by chance, I scored the winning goal. Even with the large crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, my teammates carried me around the pitch. It was amazing! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and to give them a chance to meet other players from my club. It will show them the professional environment and inspire them to believe they could play for a top team if they are willing to work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me – there will be good times, but also some challenges. I’ve had very few challenges, though – so I consider myself lucky!"

Text: 

In recent years, there has been an interesting trend in further and higher education in the UK and around the world. This trend encourages new students to get involved in research as early as possible in their studies. It acknowledges that research is not just for famous scholars at old universities or scientists making new discoveries. Instead, research is a natural way to build knowledge and skills. 

Research skills are valuable not only for your studies but also for your future job. They help you think critically about the world and how to approach your work. As a student, you contribute to knowledge. You do not just memorize and repeat information; you create it. Creating knowledge involves asking questions rather than accepting things as they are. You might wonder: Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? How does it work in this situation? What should we think about the facts, opinions, or beliefs we encounter? Why is this important? These questions are at the heart of what we call research.

Research can be seen as a range of activities. On one end, there is complex, groundbreaking research done by highly trained experts, which leads to significant changes in knowledge. However, research can also start from simple inquiries that involve careful work and thoughtful questions about various issues, practices, and events. Most students have always been researchers in some way. You have likely done research for school projects or answered questions at work since you began your education. You have asked questions that led you to investigate topics, whether it was planning a holiday, growing plants, fixing things at home, training a pet, or finding the right products online.

In college and higher education, it is expected that you will have a curious mind, identify problems and questions, critically evaluate information, and create your own responses and knowledge. Some students may find this challenging because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as fixed, and learning often involves listening to teachers and texts without questioning them. It may feel disrespectful to challenge established knowledge or authority, and you might think you should be told what is important to learn. However, in higher education in the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged.

This process of inquiry and knowledge creation can seem overwhelming. Critical thinking is especially important in research. The research done by others is valuable for students, academics, and professionals, but we must not simply repeat what we read as if it is always true. We need to engage with the information, think critically about it, test it, and determine if it is logical and supported by evidence. We should avoid blindly accepting facts and information from our readings or conversations.

Text: 'Cities have always been centers of intellectual activity, from the coffee houses of 18th-century London, where people discussed science and politics, to the cafés of modern Paris, where artist Pablo Picasso talked about art. However, living in a city is not easy. The same London cafés that encouraged discussion also helped spread diseases like cholera; Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. While modern cities can be creative places, they can also feel unnatural and overwhelming. 

Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are concerning. It has long been known that city life is tiring, but new research shows that living in cities can actually reduce our ability to think clearly. One major reason for this is the lack of nature in urban environments. Studies have shown that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even small views of nature can improve brain function because they provide a break from the stress of city life.

This research comes at a significant time: for the first time in history, more people live in cities than in rural areas. Instead of living in open spaces, we are packed into concrete environments, surrounded by many strangers. It has become clear that these unnatural surroundings can greatly affect our mental and physical health and change how we think. 

Think about everything your brain has to manage while walking down a busy street: distracted people, dangerous crossings that require attention to traffic, and the confusing layout of the city. These seemingly simple tasks can drain our energy because they force our brains to constantly shift focus. A city is filled with so many stimuli that we must continually decide what to pay attention to. This process of managing our focus takes a lot of mental energy. In contrast, natural environments do not require as much cognitive effort. 

This idea is known as attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. It has been recognized that human attention is limited – focusing in the morning makes it harder to concentrate in the afternoon. Kaplan suggested that being in nature could help restore our attention. Natural settings have elements that naturally attract our focus but do not cause negative feelings, unlike loud noises like police sirens. This allows our mental focus to relax and recharge.

Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the negative effects of city life and sought ways to include nature in urban areas. Urban parks, like Central Park in New York, provide a much-needed escape from city life. A well-designed park can enhance brain function in just a few minutes. While people have tried many methods to boost cognitive performance, such as energy drinks or redesigning office spaces, it seems that simply taking a walk in nature is one of the most effective solutions.

Given the many mental challenges caused by city life, one might wonder: Why do cities keep growing? And why do they remain important centers of intellectual activity, even in the digital age? Recent research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same urban features that can lead to attention and memory problems – like crowded streets and close proximity to others – are also linked to innovation. Scientists believe that the ‘concentration of social interactions’ is a key factor in urban creativity. Just as the crowded environment of 18th-century London led to new ideas, the busy atmosphere of 21st-century Cambridge, Massachusetts, supports its role as a hub for technology and creativity. 

The challenge, then, is to find ways to reduce the negative effects of city life while keeping its unique advantages. Because there will always be moments when someone feels, as the song says, ‘I’m tired of the trees, take me to the city!’'

**Simplified Text:**

Where should we look for the mind? This question may seem strange because we usually think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques that support this idea. However, I believe there is no strong reason to limit the study of the mind to just the brain or the body. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, showing that objects, as well as our brain cells, play a role in how we think. 

From an archaeological perspective, it is clear that items like stone tools, jewelry, carvings, clay tokens, and writing systems have actively contributed to human evolution and the development of our minds. Therefore, I propose that what exists outside our heads may also be part of our minds. It is understandable that the mind and the brain are often seen as the same because most of our knowledge about the mind comes from studying people in isolation from their surroundings. This is practical for neuroscientists, especially when using brain-scanning machines. However, this often overlooks the fact that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. 

I do not want to deny the importance of the brain in thinking, but I want to emphasize that the mind is more than just the brain. It is more useful to consider the idea that human intelligence extends beyond our bodies into culture and the material world. This is where my new theory, called Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET explores how objects can become extensions of our thinking or be integrated into our actions, like when we create numbers from clay or use a stone to make a tool. It also looks at how these interactions have changed since ancient times and what these changes mean for our thinking.

This approach provides new insights into what minds are and what they consist of by examining how objects assist our thinking. For example, think of a blind person using a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick helps us understand that minds and objects can be seen as connected. It also illustrates the flexibility of the human mind: by using the stick, the blind person transforms touch into a form of sight, and the stick itself plays an important role. The sensation felt through the stick is projected onto the environment, making the brain treat the stick as part of the body.

The blind person’s stick reminds us that human intelligence can adapt and change significantly by incorporating new technologies. I view the human mind as an ongoing project that is always evolving. It is important to remember that, regardless of what form the ‘stick’ has taken throughout our history—whether it is a simple stone tool or a modern smartphone—its main purpose is to connect us to the world rather than to limit us. 

Through the ‘stick’, humans explore, learn, and understand their environment, while also finding new paths forward. This is different from how monkeys use sticks to get food. For humans, ‘sticks’ are tools for satisfying our curiosity. This unique human ability to engage with material culture explains why we create things and how those things shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity—our minds are flexible and change as we interact with the material world. I want to emphasize the importance of material objects in understanding cognition. MET provides a new perspective on how various forms of material culture, from ancient tools to modern devices, have influenced who we are and how we think. While the idea of technology changing our minds may sound futuristic, it is important to realize that humans have been using such technology since our early evolution.

Text: "Few inventions have changed civilization as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of culture at all levels – practical, scientific, industrial, and aesthetic, as well as in entertainment. Historians argue that photography is the country’s greatest contribution to the visual arts. No other art form has had such a significant impact from the US. This claim reflects the idea that photography is central to US intellectual and aesthetic discussions, and to understand its impact, we must look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century.

Why was this new art form so appealing? First, photography was a mechanical process that matched a growing interest in technology, part of a national mindset that accepted change. Just as steam power, railroads, and electricity made communication and travel easier, photography brought the wonders of the world into homes in an immediate way. Second, the camera became the preferred tool for representing the self, allowing individuals to create public images in a society where identities were constantly being formed and reformed. Third, the camera has been important for creating and preserving family memories, even if those memories are somewhat idealized. Finally, the realism of photographs aligned with a trend towards realism in US art, focusing on everyday life.

Every photograph draws attention to something specific, showing what the photographer wants us to see. The fact that photographs are made by a machine gives them a unique quality: they are records of events, people, and things, representing what was in front of the camera and embodying a certain objectivity. However, since each photograph is taken by an individual, it also carries a personal point of view. We might look at a photograph and think we understand its meaning, leading to the idea that photography is a ‘universal language.’ Yet, the meaning of a photograph is more complex. Few subjects convey their own meaning, and no image is presented without some context that shapes our understanding, such as a caption in a newspaper or its placement in a gallery.

To understand a photograph historically, we must consider its purpose and function within its cultural context: Why did the photographer take the image? How was it first seen? Additionally, the same image can be viewed in different contexts, leading to different meanings. While the importance of the camera to artists was not widely recognized for a long time, it is now clear. In recent decades, starting with artist Andy Warhol’s use of photographs in his work, artists have been incorporating photography in various ways. In summary, photographic vision has become an essential part of painting and our understanding of representation before the invention of the camera."

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and physician, defined psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still relevant today. We all have a mental life, which gives us some understanding of what this means. Although we can study mental life in animals like rats and monkeys, it remains a complex concept. James focused on human psychology, which he believed included basic elements: thoughts, feelings, the physical world, and a way of knowing about these elements. Our knowledge is mostly personal and comes from our own experiences, which may or may not align with scientific facts.

This personal understanding can lead us to make judgments about psychological issues based on our own experiences. We often act as amateur psychologists when we share opinions on complex topics, such as whether brainwashing is effective or why people behave in certain ways. Problems can arise when two people interpret situations differently. Formal psychology aims to provide methods to determine which explanations are most likely correct in specific situations. Psychologists help us differentiate between subjective thoughts, which can be biased, and objective facts.

While psychology studies the mind and brain, psychologists do not yet fully understand how the brain works in relation to our emotions and behaviors. It is often difficult to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and forming hypotheses about what happens inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective, but the mind's workings are not directly observable like a machine's. Instead, we can only infer mental processes from behavior.

Studying psychology is similar to solving a crossword puzzle; it requires evaluating and interpreting clues. These clues must come from careful observation and accurate measurement, analyzed rigorously and interpreted logically. Psychology often involves complex interactions, and understanding these requires advanced techniques and theories. Like any science, psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and control the processes it studies. Achieving these goals can help us understand our experiences and apply findings to improve people's lives.

Psychological research has been beneficial in various areas, such as improving reading methods for children, designing safer machine controls, and helping emotionally distressed individuals communicate their feelings. Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, scientific investigation has only occurred in the last 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, or self-reflection, to answer psychological questions, focusing on identifying mental structures. While this remains important, introspection has limitations. As Sir Francis Galton noted, it only reveals a small part of the brain's automatic functions. William James compared introspection to "turning up the gas quickly enough to see how the darkness looks." Today, psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of behavior rather than solely on personal reflection.

In a storehouse located in a typical business park in Michigan, USA, there exists a unique collection known as the Museum of Failed Products. This collection, owned by a company called GfK, includes items that were taken off the market because very few people wanted to buy them. The museum's owner, Carol Sherry, believes that each product represents a story of disappointment for the designers, marketers, and salespeople involved. 

What is most surprising about this museum is that it operates as a successful business. You might think that any serious manufacturer would keep a collection of their failed products, but many executives who visit the museum show that this is not common. They often avoid thinking about their failures and do not keep samples of their unsuccessful products. The museum itself was created by Robert McMath, a former marketing professional, who originally wanted to build a reference library of consumer products, not specifically failed ones. Starting in the 1960s, he began collecting samples of every new product he could find. He did not realize that most products fail, which led to his collection being mostly made up of unsuccessful items.

Today’s optimistic culture likely contributes to the products displayed in the museum. Each product probably went through many meetings where no one recognized its potential failure. Even if they did, marketers might feel pressured to invest more money into a failing product to save face. Little effort is usually made to understand why these products failed, and those involved often choose not to discuss it again.

This tendency to focus on positivity is especially strong in the self-help industry, where a common belief is that visualizing success can lead to better outcomes. Neuroscientist Tali Sharot has found evidence that our minds may be naturally inclined to see positive outcomes as more likely than they actually are. Her research suggests that well-adjusted individuals often have an overly optimistic view of their ability to influence events compared to those who are depressed.

However, how effective are these positive thoughts about the future? Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen and her team have researched this question. Their findings are surprising: spending time imagining successful outcomes can actually reduce people's motivation to reach their goals. For instance, groups of people who were encouraged to visualize a successful week at work ended up achieving less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck explains that our experiences with failure are shaped by our beliefs about ability. People with a "fixed mindset" believe that ability is something you are born with, while those with a "growth mindset" think that ability can develop through effort and challenges. Those with a fixed mindset often find failure very distressing, seeing it as proof that they are not as capable as they thought. For example, a talented athlete might believe they are naturally gifted but fail to practice enough to reach their potential. In contrast, people with a growth mindset view failure as a sign that they are pushing their limits. Dweck compares this to weight training, where muscles grow stronger by being challenged. Ultimately, having a growth mindset is a more positive way to approach life, regardless of whether it leads to success.

Text: 'It is well-known that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is this the case? Many people think they understand it, but professional sports are changing rapidly, and what we once accepted as true is now being questioned. Two main factors are challenging the traditional view of home advantage: science and money. Sports scientists are investigating what helps players perform at their best, leading to various theories about home advantage. At the same time, those in charge of finances want to know why home advantage is still important. If players are well-paid, shouldn’t they feel comfortable playing anywhere?

This raises questions for fans. For example, would it matter if Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach their fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their team needs their support and loyalty. This belief may lead them to confuse cause and effect. When a team advances, home fans cheer loudly, and sometimes this leads to a goal, creating a loud celebration. Fans often remember the cheering before a goal but forget the many times when the cheering did not lead to success.

However, there is one common belief among fans that scientific evidence supports. Home fans not only cheer for their team but also direct their energy towards the referee. In a well-known study, referees watched a match with crowd noise and another version without sound. The referees who heard the crowd were less likely to call fouls against the home team compared to those who watched in silence. Interestingly, the crowd noise did not make them more likely to call fouls against the away team. This suggests that referees try to avoid extra stress from the crowd's reactions.

Recent studies show that home advantage has decreased in all major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the early years of the Football League in the 1890s, home teams won about 70% of the points, while today they win about 60%. One reason for this change could be travel; in the past, travel was difficult, but now players travel in great comfort. Stadiums have also become more similar, losing their unique characteristics. Despite these changes, none of the explanations fully account for the data.

The mystery remains as to why home advantage varies by sport. Basketball shows the greatest home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. One reason could be that home advantage is more about teamwork, and baseball focuses more on individual matchups. Team sports require coordination among players, and in basketball, success depends on teamwork, which is strengthened by the familiarity of playing at home.

Another possibility relates to a more primal aspect of sports. Research indicates that players’ testosterone levels are normal before training and away games but can be 67% higher before home games. This increase may be linked to a natural instinct to protect their home ground, as seen in recent Rugby World Cup matches. In two notable games, underdog teams won at home against stronger opponents, showing determination and aggression—characteristics of home advantage. As one referee put it, ‘It’s the law of the jungle out there.’"

Text: "‘The more I practice, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about fifty years ago. This saying has become famous among dedicated athletes and their coaches. The reason for its popularity is clear. First, there is debate about who originally said it, with many other golfers from that time being suggested. Second, the meaning is not straightforward. Player was not talking about luck in a literal sense; he was being ironic. His real message was: ‘The more I practice, the better I get.’ However, there is a limit to this improvement, and the question of where that limit is relates to the nature versus nurture debate – whether talent is something we are born with or something we develop through practice.

It would be misleading to call this a balanced debate; it is more like a basketball game where one side is clearly winning. The idea that practice is more important than natural talent has gained support from psychologist Anders Ericsson, who proposed that anyone can achieve expertise in any field with 10,000 hours of practice.
