I bought my first metal detector shortly after getting married. At that time, £70 was a lot of money, and I could have used it for something practical for our home. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first outing. Over the years, every brooch and coin I discovered brought me joy. I have always enjoyed feeling connected to the past. After the gold ring, it took 40 years before I found something that impressed Marion as much.

One dull February afternoon, I had a couple of hours free and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a nearby spot known for old farming machinery. When my detector first beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I tried to ignore it, but I couldn’t walk away without checking. I dug down half a meter and lay in the mud when I saw a rounded, golden ball. Having found brass curtain rails before, I tried not to get my hopes up. But as I cleared more dirt, the ball turned into a thick, beautifully patterned loop. I stopped and stared, remembering to breathe. I had seen something like this before—the Great Torc, displayed in the British Museum. It is the most famous object from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years ago. A torc is a beautiful necklace made of gold and silver, with gold rings at each end, just like the one I was holding.

I took it to my car, and at every stoplight on the way home, I looked at the torc on the passenger seat. I rinsed it in my kitchen sink, probably the only cleaning it had received since ancient times. “Marion!” I called out, “I have something for you.” As I admired my find, I heard my wife enter the room and stop. “What is it?” she asked after a moment. I explained that it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn’t try it on because we were worried about damaging it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. Although we had never been robbed, I felt anxious and restless. Eventually, I got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it underneath.

The law requires that such finds be reported to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as I could before giving it up. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I brought it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone with his back to me. When he turned around, he stopped mid-sentence. The torc was verified and later sold to my local council. It is now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 from the sale was shared between the owner of the field and me. However, the torc has meant much more to me than just a lucky find. I feel I have saved it for the nation. People often say to me, “Now that you’ve made such a great discovery, will you stop detecting?” But those brooches and coins are still interesting to me. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn’t stop fishing—there’s always the chance of catching an even bigger one tomorrow.

Text: "Sleeping is one of my greatest joys when I travel, but I don’t often talk about it because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends share their carefully planned trips, filled with activities like visiting museums and hiking, I smile and don’t say much. What would they think if they knew that my travel plans include long naps during afternoon rainstorms and lazy mornings in beautiful Italian beds? Better sleep is one of the nice benefits of traveling. When I visited Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how many hours—over 12—I spent sleeping each day. There were many loud birds nearby, but it didn’t bother me. Away from home and my own bed, surrounded by new smells and sounds, I could enjoy a deeper, more dream-filled sleep than I ever expected. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. However, I believe that the quality of sleep while traveling is not just about relaxing. I think sleep is actually part of our travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we expose ourselves to new sights, sounds, smells, and ways of living. We take in a lot of new things—cultures, music, landscapes, and even different ways of moving. It is during sleep that we process this flood of new experiences. It makes sense that sleep feels more intense when we are traveling. Sleep also changes in rhythm from place to place. People often worry about jet lag, but I think the challenges I face after long trips are more about adjusting to local cultures than just time differences. For instance, on the Caribbean island of Trinidad, people wake up at dawn to start their day before it gets too hot, slow down around 10 a.m. when the sun is high, and then become active again in the cool evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, where I live, it takes me days to adjust to the island’s different sleep and wake patterns. When I finally adapt to the local sleep schedule, I feel like I have truly arrived. I remember one afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a large lunch with new Dominican friends in a big apartment overlooking the blue Caribbean Sea. After the heavy meal and heat, our conversation faded and eventually stopped. One by one, my friends left the table to lie down on nearby hammocks and sofas. I suddenly understood why my hosts had so many pillows on the floor. I took a couple for myself and followed their lead. I had always heard about the Latin American tradition of the siesta, but that day I truly experienced it. I shared not just sleep, but a piece of Dominican life. Travel sleep has another wonderful quality: it is memorable. Away from my usual sleep routine, I find joy in the new scents, textures, and sounds that fill my mind while I sleep in a new place. If a commitment to ‘slow travel’—enjoying every moment instead of rushing to do everything—is what defines the modern traveler, then what could be slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed about my habits and be honest with my ambitious friends, explaining that travel sleep is, after all, an important part of the experience."

The woman turned away from the mirror. “What do you think? Be honest.” Mia picked up a medium-sized hat, soft with a layer of gauze and decorated with a silk bow. “I still think this one suits you best,” she said diplomatically. The woman wrinkled her nose and made a face that looked unfortunate. “But it’s so boring,” she replied. “Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little beauty will make me stand out.” She patted the red and black miniature top hat on her head. “Yes,” she said firmly, “this is the one I want.” 

Mia knew she had lost this argument. With a smile, she agreed that the woman would indeed stand out at her daughter’s wedding. She thought of her own daughter, Jen. Today was Jen’s thirtieth birthday, and they were having a family gathering. It had been a while since they had all been together, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also looking forward to meeting Jen’s friend, Tattie, whom they knew nothing about. Her husband, Jeff, had quickly pointed this out when Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie. “Tattie?” Jeff had said. “What kind of name is that?” “It’s short for Tatiana,” Mia replied. “I think it’s nice.” “More like something very pretentious,” Jeff responded. He did not like pretentiousness or anything showy. He also did not believe in “pussyfooting around,” as he called Mia’s hesitation to speak her mind. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat and probably would have said that a dustbin lid would look better on her. “The trouble with you, Mia,” he often said, “is that you’re too polite for your own good.”

An hour later, Mia closed her shop and entered Medlar House through the back door; her commute took only forty seconds. Four years ago, when Luke, their youngest child, left home, Mia decided to convert the unused barn next to the house into a bright space for her business. Jeff had been doubtful. “Do you really think there’s a demand for hats?” he asked. Mia knew from her friends that finding the perfect hat for special occasions was difficult, so she was sure there was a demand. She was right. From the first day, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats became a success. Women traveled from far away to her showroom in Little Pelham, where she provided a relaxed environment for them to try on as many hats as they needed. With changing rooms available, she encouraged customers to bring their outfits to ensure a perfect match. Recently, she had expanded her business to include handbags and costume jewelry as well.

Text: 

It is a long journey from London to Atlanta, and at his new home in America, Lawrence Okoye reflects on his incredible sports journey. He is confident but seems surprised by how far he has come, from competing in an Olympic final in discus to possibly starting a new career. Although he has never played American football before, Lawrence is likely to be chosen for one of the major teams in the USA. In Atlanta, he is still figuring out the responsibilities of his new position.

The idea that a 21-year-old beginner from London could be selected for one of the biggest teams in American sports is surprising. However, Lawrence is known for proving doubters wrong. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but decided to focus on training for discus after previously playing rugby. Within 20 months of starting, he became the world’s fourth-best discus thrower.

Lawrence originally came to Atlanta for warm-weather training for the discus, preparing for the world championships. When asked about his sudden interest in American football, he confirms, “Yes, it was in the back of my mind, but I only decided to try it when I got to the USA.” He had thought about it while in school in London, but it seemed unrealistic then. After arriving in America, he learned about the NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played the game, he felt confident enough to apply for the trials. 

When asked if he was nervous about competing against experienced players, he replied, “No, not at all. I don’t get nervous for many things.” Although he is not very talkative, he is sure of his abilities. His performance in various tests made him stand out as the most impressive player. “I was very happy to hear that,” he said, showing a rare moment of pride.

However, he is also cautious. He lacks basic experience, so how can he make it onto an NFL team? “Coaches have told me I have the right qualities. It’s all about how hard I work,” he said. Will he be relaxed while waiting to hear if he has been selected? “I will be. There’s no pressure on me. Many people say I will definitely be chosen, but I’m not too worried.”

This calmness may come from his disappointing Olympic final, where he finished last. He seems to have moved on from that experience and is proud that he qualified for the final with an impressive last throw. “That was an amazing day,” he said. “The final didn’t go as I wanted, but that’s part of sports. It’s something I can return to.”

After his Olympic disappointment, some speculated that he let the experience affect him. Lawrence chooses not to comment on that. The minimum salary for an NFL player is over $400,000 a year, which is a strong financial incentive. So, Lawrence has moved from rugby to athletics and now to American football. Given his many talents, wouldn’t it be better to focus on just one sport? “I understand why someone would say that,” he replied. “I’m trying to achieve something I’ve dreamed about since I was a kid. If it doesn’t work out, I can always return to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I’ve made has been thought out.”

Text: 'We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to find it was already daylight. Looking out of the window at the empty landscape below, the dark shades of brown and green reassured me that, even though it was mid-September, autumn had not yet arrived in Siberia. I saw no signs of human life, just a strange mix of mountains, streams, and forests stretching to the horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled sleepily at me. “Good morning, Robert,” he said, saying my name with a slow Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow, traveling to the remote areas to sell safety clothing to local mining companies. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I managed to tell him that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with a one-way ticket because I planned to return home to England by bicycle. “But, Robert,” he argued, “there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle.” I explained that I believed there was a road, though not many people used it anymore. “Alone?” he asked, pointing at me. “No, I will be riding with a friend named Al.” “Just one friend?” “Yes, just one,” I nodded. Sergei still looked doubtful and pointed outside, saying “Holodna” (cold). I tried to convince him with hand gestures that I had plenty of warm clothes, but I didn’t mention that I was on a tight budget for my trip. Most of my clothes and gear were bought at low prices. In reality, I wasn’t sure they would be good enough, especially my large postman’s over-trousers that I had bought for £10. 

It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. That morning, the hall was full of students slumped in their seats. Some were taking notes without much energy. The lecturer droned on. I was thinking hard about a dilemma. Should I ask him or not? “Well, why not?” I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, “Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob.” In the row in front of me sat Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my handwriting, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. “OK,” it said. Six years later, I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I still struggled to control my classes fully, the job met many important needs for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, and often fulfilling, plus there were long holidays to pursue adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I had used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventure bug after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more relaxing than teaching: to cycle around the world. Since that first ride together, Al had been taking on bigger and bigger challenges. This round-the-world bike trip was certainly his biggest yet. Sometimes he thought the ride would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him in many ways. He was having an extraordinary adventure, proving he could handle each new challenge, even when it seemed impossible. He was showing the skeptics who said he couldn’t do it that they were wrong. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.'

In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots compete by flying through a series of pylons that are between 15 and 25 meters high. They perform sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops at speeds of up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it feels like to participate. An hour before my flight, I had to sign two forms. The first confirmed that I was healthy, and the second stated that I would empty my pockets, as small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I learned that I needed to stay oriented throughout the experience. “The horizon is your best friend,” I was told, and the pilot would guide me on where to look. I was also asked to promise that when flying upside down, I would “completely relax and try to enjoy the view.”

Half an hour before the flight, I attended a safety briefing where I was instructed not to touch anything. As we began taxiing down the runway, I was nervous. My legs were up, my feet avoided the important steering pedals, and my hands stayed away from the many switches nearby. Despite the instructions, I found it hard to relax and enjoy the flight. This is the challenge of high-speed acrobatic flying: to survive without fainting, you must stay calm and focused, tensing and relaxing at the right moments. Panicking is not an option.

As we accelerated down the runway, I felt anxious. Dario, the pilot, and I were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes in the world. The plane took off, and just two seconds later, we made a sharp right turn. It was a sudden, intense movement, and I felt the air rush out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and gasped as I sank into my seat. For a brief moment, I felt 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out, turned sharply left, and dove down, leaving my stomach behind at 2,000 meters.

Seconds later, we were just 10 meters off the ground, heading for a small gap between two pylons. We passed them at 400 km per hour, but my moment of excitement was interrupted by another sharp turn. I was allowed to fly the plane for two minutes, but my hand shook so much that the plane shook too. Then Dario spoke, but I couldn’t hear him. Instead of answering, he performed a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. “Are you okay?” he asked. “Yup.” “Have you had enough?” “No,” I lied. Then he did a loop, flying up and over in a full circle. 

I know many people would find this thrilling, like those who enjoy rollercoasters. However, I thought it was overwhelming. At the top of the loop, while upside down, I heard a voice saying, “Relax, relax, look up.” I looked up and saw fields below. The flight lasted 10 minutes and felt “soft” compared to what the pilots experience during races. To illustrate this, Dario pulled out sandwiches as soon as we landed and happily started eating. I didn’t eat for hours, and that night, I kept dreaming about the loop over and over again.

Doug Allan is a filmmaker who captures wild animals in cold environments. If you have ever been impressed by videos of polar bears in a nature documentary, it is likely that he filmed them. He believes that his ideal temperature is -18°C. Allan studied marine biology and worked as a commercial diver. Diving was his first love, where he learned how to survive in cold conditions. His big opportunity came when a TV crew arrived in Antarctica, where he was working, to make a wildlife documentary. "I ended up guiding the crew to various locations, and after 48 hours, I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, and underwater experiences," he explains. He is now a leading cameraman and has contributed to many important wildlife TV series.

"I started at a good time. When I began, very few people had been to Antarctica. There were experts for coral, elephants, and chimpanzees. I became known as the cold expert. It felt like there were incredible scenes just waiting to be filmed." When he started 35 years ago, the camera and communication technology were very basic. "Filming is definitely easier now. Back then, if you recorded something, you had to remember it. Today, with digital technology, you can shoot a lot and review it immediately. You had to plan your shots carefully, and film was very costly. Now, it’s easy to end up with too much footage."

"My strength is my experience in cold environments. I feel comfortable there. I have spent so much time on sea ice that it feels as easy as crossing the street. I do get cold toes, but the polar regions are healthy places. There are no leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes." Allan notes that wildlife filming has many successes, but also failures and awkward moments. Once, while in the Orkneys filming kittiwakes, he could not identify the birds.

Recently, Allan received permission to film for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean. He knew it would be a challenging task. This area is home to polar bears and is only accessible to the bravest or most reckless. In April, temperatures are usually around -32°C, the winds are harsh, and carrying cameras through deep snow is very difficult. After walking for five or more hours each day and observing polar bear dens for 23 days, Allan had only seen one mother bear and her cub. However, on the 24th day, he felt as if he was in the bears' world, moving at their pace and sensing their presence. 

"We find a new hole and wait. We shuffle, hop, bend, stretch, and run to keep warm. After five hours of watching, suddenly I catch a quick glimpse that I almost miss. But the camera is focused on the hole, and my eye is quickly on the viewfinder. After a few seconds, I see an unmistakable black nose. The nose becomes a muzzle, then a full head, and in less than a minute, she emerges from the hole, resting on the snow. She looks at me but seems unbothered. Just as I think it can't get any better, she slides down the slope, and I believe she is enjoying herself," he recalls, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. "Clearly, it’s their first look at the world. It’s showtime on the slopes, and we have front-row seats."

Now, Allan wants to create his own film about climate change in the Arctic, speaking with the local people who experience its effects firsthand. He believes he could make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk alone to the North Pole without getting supplies along the way. This journey involved swimming in extremely cold waters and facing dangers like frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole as well. Now, he is back in the Arctic, preparing for an even more ambitious expedition. Explorers like Pen are confident and determined individuals, which is essential for their work. This time, however, the stakes are much higher. Pen and two colleagues will embark on a three-month, 1,000-kilometre trek to the North Pole, where they will take detailed measurements of the ice's thickness and density. No one has done this before, and Pen understands that the results will be crucial for scientists. This expedition will provide a clearer understanding of how global warming is affecting the polar ice.

Pen was prepared for this kind of work from a young age. He was raised by his father's old nanny, who had worked for the famous polar explorer, Scott of the Antarctic. She toughened him up by sending him out into harsh weather with minimal clothing. His father also inspired his love for adventure in cold places, and Pen developed remarkable physical endurance. He is married to Mary, a horsewoman who shares his passion for the outdoors. Mary helps run his polar guide business and often worries about him more when he is at home, saying, "He’s in more danger driving along the A303 because I know that in his head he’s somewhere in the Arctic." For fun, she once raced against him in a mountain event, finishing an hour ahead of him. 

Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. He admits that it is much harder to be away from them this time. When he last went on an expedition, his children were one and five years old. He made a mistake in how he said goodbye, telling his son to take care of his mother and sister. His son took this seriously and constantly checked on them, which became too much for him. Although Pen meant well, he feels it was unfair. For this trip, he plans to have very little contact with his family while in the Arctic, as he believes that calling them would remind them of how far away he is.

In the days leading up to his departure, Pen is meticulously preparing his equipment. He knows that once he is on the ice, it will be very difficult to fix anything or do anything complicated. He will be joined by Ann Daniels, a leading polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer. They will have a support crew of six who will fly in supplies. Pen finds being part of a team more stressful, and he is also concerned about his upcoming 47th birthday. He feels he has not trained as much as he would like, as organizational tasks have taken priority. He is worried about what he will demand of himself during the expedition.

Pen believes that his mission connects exploration with the pursuit of knowledge that motivated earlier explorers. He admits that reaching the North Pole was mainly a personal goal and had limited value beyond the polar adventure community. This time, however, scientists will benefit from the data collected, and they aim to engage as many people as possible in understanding what is happening in the Arctic Ocean. He emphasizes that this is important work, and they are uniquely qualified to do it. "Our skills, which may seem strange and unnecessary in everyday life, have become extremely relevant. Suddenly, we are socially useful again," he says.

Text: "I took a 'year off'. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is a wonderful experience. I had the opportunity to do more writing and TV work, and to speak to businesses and schools. Although I enjoyed these activities, I felt there was nothing competitive to focus on. I wanted to stay in shape so I could compete for an Olympic spot if that dream came back to me. So, I signed up for marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle’s invitation: 'Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?' I have always loved rowing and the feeling of the boat moving through the water. I missed that feeling, but I wasn’t ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked some of my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but they weren’t very interested. I knew that if I entered the race, even though it was called an adventure, I would want to win. Would rowing with Ben give me the best chance to win? No. But being an underdog without pressure was appealing. I contacted Ben. He was going to enter the race anyway and had managed to gather the large entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We discussed the other costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000 – a lot of money. We believed we had a better chance than most, but it would still require effort to secure funding. Additionally, I had to consider the loss of income from being away from home. Speaking at business conferences is one of the best ways to earn money as a retired athlete. It’s nice that people are interested, but I find it hard to talk about my past achievements without a new goal. Joining the race would mean I wouldn’t just be discussing my past; I would actually be doing something again: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one of the biggest lessons was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. My preparation for the Olympics was tough, with my life focused on getting in the best shape; but looking back, it was quite simple. Yes, I trained almost every day, but the training program was set, and there were doctors and dieticians. I was worried about how people would react to me racing with a TV presenter. I feared it would seem like I just wanted to be on TV, otherwise I would have chosen a better partner to win the race. However, my concerns faded as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is about more than just rowing; it’s also about mental strength. Ben had completed the difficult Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and lived on a deserted island. However, he couldn’t row well. I was surprised by how little natural ability he had for rowing, and he was surprised by my lack of understanding. I could have been more patient, but I felt it was important to be honest with Ben about the significant improvements he needed to make. I should have realized that this would be his level when I agreed to race with him."

Text: 

Just over a year ago, I left my job in London to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I felt restless and dreamed of cold, vast landscapes, perhaps because I was tired of the noise and crowds of the city. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They offered me a position as a husky dog handler for the busy winter season. From December to February, they take tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the snow and ice, for trips ranging from one hour to five days. They started with six dogs, but now have over 100. Recently, they acquired a second location called the 'wilderness farm,' which they described as a beautiful but basic place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months, but warned me that the hours would be long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical. I began packing right away.

November 6, London  
On my flight, I stared at a page with over 100 pictures of huskies. I was supposed to memorize their names before I arrived, but I felt distracted and anxious. I put the page down and looked out the window instead. I remembered that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. However, I felt like I was witnessing winter moving south, as rivers froze over.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta  
The bus ride north was everything I hoped for. We drove through endless dark forests of thin conifer trees weighed down by snow, stopping occasionally for reindeer. I arrived at the farm after dark, and as soon as I entered, I was given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. Anna asked, "Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?" It was a rhetorical question. I followed the sound of barking, which grew louder as I approached the dogsheds. Three people were running back and forth, pulling huskies out and harnessing them to sleds. The dogs were excited, straining against their ropes. I could barely introduce myself, but the others were too busy to talk. I stood to the side and petted one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestured for me to join in, and I almost fell into the nearest sled. A command was shouted, and we took off into the dark, guided only by a headlamp.

November 15, Hetta  
I quickly learned the basics of being a husky guide, but first, I faced a challenging quiz about my skills. "Are you useful?" Anna asked. I was unsure. Further questions revealed that I was not very useful: I had never driven a snowmobile, hadn’t done woodwork since school, and had never chopped anything with an axe. Finally, someone asked if I had a driving license, and I nodded, feeling relieved. 

I learned the basics of dog-sledding quickly: lean into the corners, use both feet on the brake to stop, and never let go of the handlebar. However, other tasks were complicated. Simple things like feeding and watering the dogs became difficult in freezing temperatures. A bowl of water would freeze quickly, so we had to make a 'soup' of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head was full of instructions, and my muscles ached from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled around by eager huskies. But I felt proud. I emailed my friends, "I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw—in the snow!"

On that day, as Radcliffe ran past the finish line, reporters gathered to understand her amazing performance. They noted that her time was fast enough to qualify for the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about a natural remedy, emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had suggested to help heal injuries Radcliffe suffered when she accidentally collided with a bike during training. Radcliffe claims that the significance of her achievement didn’t fully hit her at the time. Looking back, she realizes it was a major accomplishment, but she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day, so it didn’t feel overwhelming. She and her support team had decided not to set any limits, following their motto: no limits.

During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio coverage. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was also with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent expressed concern about her pace, fearing it might cause her to drop out. Hartmann was frustrated by this worry, although he acknowledged that anyone unfamiliar with her fitness might see it as a risk to start so quickly.

With 800 meters left, Radcliffe began to calculate her finish time. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she crossed the line in less than three minutes. After running 41 kilometers at a fast pace, she managed to sprint the final distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." She remembered the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never expected to see anyone come close to that time for a long time, and she thought, "I will come back and do it next year." Unfortunately, that did not happen.

After the race, many were curious about how an athlete with such an unusual running style had outperformed the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had spent weeks with Radcliffe, providing daily training sessions to support her as she covered 250-300 kilometers each week. He stated, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one on the treatment table could handle that level of pain. She would push me to my limits; I had to ice my thumbs afterward because I was in so much pain."

Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from his home in Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no friendly greeting or offer of tea; as soon as he arrived, she was ready for a two-hour training session. "Paula would push you to your limits. That's what made her so exceptional." During this time, Hartmann dedicated so much of his energy to Radcliffe that his other athletes became frustrated.

Can Radcliffe explain why no one has come close to her record? "Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought Mary Keitany (two-time London marathon winner) might achieve it. Maybe it's because people are competing against each other rather than focusing on their own performance." What does she mean by that? "It's about that mental attitude of never easing up, even when you’re winning. That mindset probably helped me because I never thought, 'I can relax now.' It was always about pushing myself as hard as I could." Radcliffe did not realize at the time that this marathon would be the peak of her career; she would never run that fast again. However, she did inspire many women to take up long-distance running.

Text: "When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. There was a lot of discussion about a 'food revolution' happening in Britain, and I believed we had created a series that contributed something new to this movement. However, I worried whether people would appreciate a cooking approach that included not just techniques but also history, nostalgia, and science. I watched the first episode feeling both excited and anxious. Fortunately, the show was successful, leading to many other interesting projects, including a book based on my experiences at my restaurant. Each project felt like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques.

I later wrote several books in a series called 'Perfection,' each linked to its own TV show. In these books, the journey was often physical, involving passports, suitcases, and travel plans. The latest book, In Search of Total Perfection, takes you around the world to meet remarkable artisans, like a man who dedicates his life to making golden pasta that tastes exceptional. These artisans have spent years pursuing their own ideas of perfection. 

Perfection is subjective. Even choosing which dishes to feature in the series was challenging, and I knew I would disappoint some people by not including their favorites. I could imagine them asking, 'Where’s steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?' However, after a long meeting with the TV production team, we created a list that would satisfy many tastes. This experience reinforced my belief that everyone has their own idea of perfection, shaped by personal emotions, memories, and environments.

Despite the book's title, I never claimed the recipes were 'definitive.' I believed that by using my skills and knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could identify what made these dishes special. The dictionary defines 'perfection' as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation—trying ideas and refining them until something unique emerges.

The TV series allowed me to explore various foods, people, and places I had never seen in restaurants. I was excited to delve into memory and nostalgia in food, as I began my career in a similar way. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. I had many adventures, such as visiting a canning factory that was processing the wrong type of tomato and a dairy farm that did not meet our standards for perfection, which forced us to stop filming. While refining each recipe, I even hand-milked a cow and used dry ice to make ice cream, cooked chicken in a hospital scanning machine, and almost burned my house down trying to heat the oven for a proper Neapolitan-style pizza."

Text: 'We were still a long way from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, swerved off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the hood. He looked at the engine for a long time with his hands in his pockets, looking like he knew what he was doing. “Actually, I have no idea what I’m doing,” he finally admitted, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, “We can’t stay here forever,” she said. The field went on for miles, filled with grass and many flowers, like poppies and daisies. “No, we can’t stay here forever,” I agreed, as it was best to support Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John get smaller as he walked away to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay down on the grass. “Tell us a story,” she said. Bea lay down next to her. “Go on, tell us a story.” So I shared a story about how, the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I told them everything the birds discussed: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. “That’s silly, no one understands bird language,” Bea said. My eyes felt wet. “I do.” But I didn’t sound very sure. “Liar.” I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? The more I thought about it, the less sure I became. “Mum…?” But she had fallen asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind; they waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café that was a little away from the road, not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “It might be a bit expensive.” “We’ll just have some tea,” Mum said, and we sat in the shade of the terrace. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. “It’s like syrup,” she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. “It’s a miracle it got us this far,” he said as it started to get dark. Mum took blankets out onto the road and made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on solid ground. “I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,” John said from the other side of Mum. Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept wondering how we would get home now that our van had to be towed. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.'

Text: Lucy was at a welcome party in the hotel ballroom, talking to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were older than her by about ten years. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city whose name Lucy didn’t quite catch. They spoke good English and discussed the music they were playing and their recent travels. Lucy mentioned, “I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer.” It sounded impressive, but she didn’t really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She often felt overwhelmed by the concerts and competitions that took her around the world, making her miss so much school that she wasn’t officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco.

Lucy hadn’t even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which selected only fifteen pianists her age from around the world. She had been chosen from thousands of applicants. Her dad celebrated by buying her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant, and her little brother Gus dreamed of being at the same festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The truth was, Lucy hadn’t applied herself; her mother had filled out the form and sent in a CD. “I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,” her mom had said. Lucy thought, “More like you didn’t want to give me the chance to say no.” Back then, she believed that causing trouble was the worst thing to do, so she didn’t think about refusing.

The guy from Tokyo leaned in, seeming surprised. “Tanglewood?” he asked. “Yeah.” “How old are you?” “Fifteen.” He exchanged a look with the girl, who said, “Wow.” Lucy hadn’t meant to brag; it was hard to know when sharing was showing off. “It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they’re trying…” The girl then looked across the room, as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. The guy stayed and asked, “Have you ever been to Japan?” He had long, shaggy hair, like many musicians, showing they were cool in their own way. “Once, when I was about eight.” He started to respond when Lucy's grandfather appeared beside her. “Lucy, let me introduce you to someone.” He took her arm and pulled her away from the conversation. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” “They’re not the competition.” “Everyone is the competition.” 

Her grandfather took her around the room, making her talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, understanding only part of what was said. In the elevator to their suite after leaving the party, her grandfather said, “You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” She liked that part—being someone important—even if it meant some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention she received. Being a concert pianist didn’t earn her respect from the kids at her old school. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn’t know or care that she could play a Rachmaninov piece perfectly. But in places like this, Lucy felt she mattered.

Text: "‘Spending too much time online isn’t good for you. You should spend more time in the real world,’ said Dad. It’s hard to argue with him, so I decided to look into what experts say about this topic – and it’s quite interesting. Research shows that many teenagers who use social media have a large group of real-life friends, a strong sense of identity, and are developing important technical skills needed in today’s digital world. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, states that ‘social networking is now a key part of growing up. Teenagers don’t just use media like adults do; they live in it. This isn’t necessarily good or bad – it depends on how you use it.’ 

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, describes it as ‘the modern version of hanging out at the youth club, where today’s parents used to share jokes and gossip: a kind of virtual youth club.’ He explains that it helps teenagers form their identity away from their parents and learn to handle teenage issues while connecting with their peers. 

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says, ‘Adolescence is a time for self-discovery. Social networking can help you find your identity: you can share your favorite music or sports, explore your interests, and see that others have different perspectives. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don’t use social media.’ He adds that social media can be helpful for shy people: ‘Communicating online can feel easier than face-to-face, and it allows you to practice social skills in a less stressful setting.’ 

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can be beneficial for quiet individuals with specific interests because they connect with others who share those interests. ‘If you’re one of only a few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social networking group of similar people, you can feel part of a community and still be popular in a different way,’ he explains. 

Pauline White, a digital education expert, shared something interesting: ‘Young people who discover new interests online, join networks of like-minded individuals, and create their own content are truly making the most of social networks.’ She believes social networking is becoming a creative outlet: teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about their interests. Photo-sharing sites are changing how creativity is expressed. Enthusiastic photographers can connect, learn skills, share images, and deepen their passion. ‘This enhances employability and will be valuable in the workplace,’ she says. ‘Every business uses social media to promote and build brand awareness – understanding how it works is essential. For instance, if you create a product and have 1000 friends on various social networks, they could all be potential customers. Linking these networks creates your customer base.’ 

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and enter the job market, agrees Matthews. ‘One great aspect of many sites is the chance to collaborate with others to create and share content. Collaboration is a vital skill in the 21st century and is important for being employable in a digital world.’"

Text: 

When people think of a relaxing family vacation, they might not imagine a long trip across nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. However, my parents were not looking for a quiet getaway when they planned our summer vacation this year. My dad seemed determined to create what he thought was the ultimate family bonding experience. “Not enough people do this anymore,” he and my mother said repeatedly before our trip, while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, “There must be good reasons for that!”

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and a variety of clothes for any weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. Still, I had some strategies to cope. With barely enough space left for us, we began “The Family Great American Road Trip.” Leaving our spacious home for smaller places over the next five thousand miles made me wonder what we had gotten ourselves into.

We headed west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had our share of adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the highway by a dust storm. We quickly learned that cattle have the right-of-way on the road!

The next day, we woke up early and continued our journey. I noticed a pattern: the desert changed to mountains. The days started to blend together, but each adventure was still unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado, where we experienced the strong smell of sulfur. As we climbed to our next destination, we realized that the roads marked for Jeeps were best for actual Jeep drivers.

Everywhere we stopped, we saw a mix of old and new. Dealing with construction traffic became normal. Disappointment turned to laughter when we took pictures next to the large “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. “Bear jams,” where traffic would stop to let bears cross, were common, and our close encounter with a bear (and a worried park ranger) gave us unforgettable memories.

As we drove, life back home faded away. Even the hotel we stayed in, which was an old building with no internet or cell phone service, couldn’t dampen our excitement. In exchange for these inconveniences, I experienced some of the most beautiful views I’ve ever seen. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, my family and I headed back south. My parents were right: you don’t need to travel to a faraway place to find something amazing. 

Returning home together was a mix of emotions, but at least I hadn’t argued with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our journey to look through and remember. I knew that the moments I would cherish most were the unplanned and spontaneous ones.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Her family was separating for two years because her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy needed to finish her last year of school, so it was better for her to remain at the college where she had the best room, complete with a kitchen and study area. She also had free access to the Internet and phone. Jeff and Dahlia would keep an eye on Amy, whether she liked it or not. 

Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She only had vague memories of Daisy from past holidays and had never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not excited about it, but Daisy insisted it was no trouble and was eager to reconnect with Rose. Rose didn’t fully understand why her parents had issues with her grandmother, but there had been a disagreement in the past, leading to summers spent away from Daisy. Rose remembered her last goodbye at age ten, and those memories were happy. Dahlia had said that living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and had a talent for bringing people together. Rose could expect dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon, which made her smile. Daisy was not a typical frail old lady; she seemed to attend more social events than anyone else.

Before the move, Dahlia and Rose had a serious talk. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She understood healthy eating, fitness, and the importance of sleep. However, she wanted one thing: her independence. Living with Daisy would meet her needs, but Rose wanted to play music loudly, invite friends over, and go out without asking for permission every time. She believed she could be trusted with these small things. She didn’t want to be nagged about homework or curfews, and she didn’t want to be dragged around by her grandmother. Daisy understood.

Dahlia had given Rose a new touch-screen mobile phone with a video camera for emergencies only, which made Rose very happy. They all agreed that it would be about trust from now on. Daisy would trust Rose to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If either of them crossed a line, they would talk about it again.

Rose had never been a wild child. Her few school friends were similar, so her school reports were always good, and her exam results were excellent. This helped her a lot. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. This would be her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. At least she knew this would be the last time, as she would be starting her final two years of school. For Rose, it was a new chapter in her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first person to suggest she might write a novel. She thought writing a book would be a great achievement because it seemed challenging, and she wasn’t aware of what other teenagers were doing, like competing in the Olympics. When she turned 13, she decided to give it a try. Now, the novel she started at that age is about to be published. Recently, she told her former teacher about it, and the teacher was surprised. She had thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40. Charlotte found this surprising because she didn’t see why she should wait to pursue something she might be good at.

It’s a winter afternoon in the offices of Charlotte’s publishers. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was still surprised to see a teenager sitting there. The book is a significant achievement: the story is confident and full of action. Nothing about it, except for the age of its main character, suggests it was written by a teenager. A public relations representative is with us in case Charlotte needs support, but she doesn’t. She is independent, lively, and intelligent, but also calm, which keeps her from being overly confident.

Charlotte recognizes the limits of her youth. When I ask her about the complex moral issues in her book, she says, “I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers.” She laughs and adds, “I don’t think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I also don’t consider myself particularly wise. I was just interested in the theme of taking responsibility.”

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are often misrepresented in fiction. She believes there are three types of teenagers in novels: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the socially awkward teenager. Reading about these character types frustrated her. “What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about characters who aren’t inadequate in some way. Some writers unintentionally give the impression that teenagers can’t know who they are because they lack experience, and that can hurt their self-confidence.”

Charlotte has always enjoyed reading famous fantasy authors, but their work almost discouraged her from writing. “My favorite fantasy books explore deep psychological themes. I wondered if I needed to write like that to create a good book and if I was capable of it.” However, she appreciates a book called How Not to Write a Novel, which advises that if readers start to guess what will happen next, the suspense is likely gone.

Some might argue that Charlotte’s parents, both journalists, played a key role in getting her novel published. Her father’s connection in publishing helped her book get read initially. She acknowledges her good luck, as it is difficult for anyone to get a first novel read, regardless of their age. “Every aspiring writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you’re on your own. Ultimately, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted,” Charlotte concludes.

Text: 

“Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,” said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. “Now, who wants to go first?” The group looked nervous. Then David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping and wanted to show he knew what he was doing, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He hit the ramp quickly and flew into the air, arms flailing. Even to our inexperienced eyes, something seemed off. We held our breath. He landed hard, losing both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. “Remember,” Gareth kindly reminded us, “speed can be unpredictable.” 

Maybe freestyle skiing wasn’t for me. On previous skiing trips, I had enjoyed practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers who did tricks on ramps and half pipes in skate parks. I thought it looked fun, but I felt that if I tried to join the skateboarders, with their baggy pants and special language, I would be laughed at. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training centre in the US. It had a large indoor facility with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow, where students practiced their tricks and landed in foam pits – not exactly a realistic start for what awaited us on the slopes. 

After practicing indoors, students went outside to try their moves for real. “Progression is inevitable!” the centre’s slogan cheerfully promised. “Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,” said Gareth. “But remember – if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.” The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope steepens again for landing. If you land in the zone, you keep moving forward, which reduces impact. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which hurts. So, speed is important. 

At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore what my brain was telling me and to race towards the jump. My legs seemed to go into reverse as I neared the launch point, and I landed hard on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt exhausted. “You need to control the jump, not let it control you,” said Gareth. 

Day two began on the trampolines. I thought I would dislike being indoors, looking at the snowy mountains outside, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some drills mimicked ski-jumping moves, while others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – understanding what your body is doing while spinning in the air. Gareth provided a running commentary. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed improvement – every time I tried, I was aware of the moment before take-off, and then nothing until I found myself lying in the foam cubes next to the trampoline. 

We returned to the mountain to try again. There were more challenges before I finally landed properly. Gareth seemed as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud of achieving such a difficult goal. But that feeling didn’t last long. On my last run of the day, I forced myself to keep my speed up as I approached the jump, became airborne, and landed correctly in the landing zone. Then I noticed both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer attached to my feet.

Text: 'Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your palms are sweaty with fear, and your nails dig into the harness as the ride comes to a stop. You take a deep breath before the carriage slowly climbs upwards. There is a pause, then a sudden drop that makes your stomach feel weightless. With your teeth clenched, you speed forward, turn sharply left, and go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you let out a scream of fear. But you have only yourself to blame: like millions of others each year, you chose to pay to enter the theme park. 

What is interesting to me is that amusement parks, with their thrilling rides designed to attract crowds, are a massive industry. To create the excitement and escape from reality that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers, designers, and marketing experts working behind the scenes. The idea of being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a childhood dream, but it is actually a significant challenge. Designers must find the right balance between fun and fear while ensuring the safety of passengers. They also need to introduce new features to keep visitors interested. 

While many people think that rollercoasters have become more intense over time, most of the techniques used today, like the wheels that allow rides to go upside down, were developed by US designer John Miller in the early 20th century. During his 'golden age' of rollercoasters, many extreme designs were tested, often to the discomfort of riders. Now, designers must work within the limits set by specialized ride manufacturers. 

I spoke to three experts in rollercoaster design. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer' with a background in aeronautics, explained that the skill lies in putting all the elements together. Dr. John Roberts, a fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering, added that it involves quickly alternating between feelings of excitement and safety, so riders feel thrilled but not unsafe. 

To create an exceptional ride, the teams behind rollercoasters must develop a strong story, whether it’s a space adventure or a fast-paced jungle chase, that complements any new features like the tallest drops or most twists. However, Professor Walker noted that, like in many creative fields, intuition, experience, and trial-and-error are crucial. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed that it helps to be passionate about thrills to understand what riders want and to test the rides before they open to the public. 

I asked the experts if rollercoaster designers would need to adopt new technologies, like virtual reality. Walker responded that while virtual reality can enhance the experience, it is not a replacement for the physical thrill of a rollercoaster. He believes that the traditional rollercoaster experience will continue to be the main attraction for many years.'

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already accomplished a lot as a choreographer, creating works for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances occasionally. I wonder why she manages to do both activities in her busy life. She explains, “Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio, following the instructions of demanding choreographers, and how stressful that can be. Choreographers can forget what it feels like to rehearse all day.”

As a choreographer, she takes on a teaching role and enjoys working with young students. “A beginner dancer is often open to trying new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They are eager for success but don’t yet fully understand their strengths and weaknesses. Their unclear view of their skills helps them accept even tough criticism. However, they might still question what I say, and I appreciate their honest feedback.”

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, letting the music guide her. “There might be music I don’t like, but I still aim to create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a certain piece, it can be frustrating, but I must find solutions. I won’t go back and choose a new piece. Ideally, I’d like to experiment more and have the option to switch music – it would definitely help improve the mood during tough rehearsals. Unfortunately, I often work on large productions where the music is already decided by the composer.”

Miranda does not want to be tied to one institution. “I think it’s important to keep meeting new people. However, I must remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. So, I need to adapt my approach each time I go somewhere new, rather than just repeat what I’ve done before. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.”

The conversation shifts to a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. “There have been glamorous documentaries in the past that were misleading,” Miranda says. “This one tries to show an accurate picture of life in a dance company. There’s a scene where a young dancer receives many corrections, and I smiled because I recognized that moment. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch but very real. The public often underestimates the amount of work and dedication required in ballet.”

I ask Miranda what makes a great ballet or dance production. “It’s when everything the company has put in – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – comes together. Perfection might be too much to expect, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can allow for a few artistic mistakes. I’ve been part of productions where the dance steps are excellent, but something about the costumes or props is distracting, and that’s disappointing.”

Given her wide range of work, I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? “People often want to label you, and I don’t quite understand that. There’s also a modern trend to encourage expertise in a narrow area. I don’t follow that, but maybe one day I’ll be happy to be known for one thing. For now, I just want to expand my horizons.”

Text: "A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that there are amazing things on TV, but why stay at home when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation inspired my unusual four-day trip and a film that encourages people to turn off their TVs. A friend was giving away his old sofa, which became the main focus of the film. I added three wheels and some cables to it and attached old seatbelts over my shoulders. I placed my luggage on the sofa and slept on it each night, including one night on the beach. Several friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and motivating me to keep going. I have done many walking trips in recent years, but this was completely different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I walked on main roads, which allowed me to stop at roadside cafés and enjoy a cappuccino on the sofa instead of eating sandwiches on a rock. I often had to tell people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to share how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website."

Text: 'When I read about guided swimming trips around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I had traveled with before, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be a good idea. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained that I wouldn’t be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the small islands. Although he still seemed confused, he smiled and showed me on board. 

Our group had exchanged emails before we left, but there was little time to talk before our first swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would follow us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first proper swim of 1.5 km, which made me nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. However, I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was very happy when I finally did it on my own.

The following days had a routine: jumping in, finding a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the scenery. As the swims became longer, my speed and enjoyment also increased. I felt less need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come back again next year.'

Text: "Being a flight attendant is not easy, but since I started this job, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have plenty of time off, and my life is always interesting, which makes it a great job for someone young like me! As a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family, so I often flew alone at the beginning and end of each term. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I would ask the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to passengers, and some of them let me. This experience stayed in my mind when I wanted to leave my banking job and look for a new path. 

At the interview, there were many young people, and many were hired. They were often well-qualified like me and were changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say, focusing on my strengths and past work experience, rather than just saying I loved to travel, which everyone else would say. This approach helped me get the job! 

I would recommend this job to anyone because there are many rewarding aspects, although the free flights are not the main reason. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: 'no one is finished until everyone is finished.' It feels like a big family; even if we don’t see each other often, we are still close. When I am not working, I don’t have to take work home with me. If I do encounter difficult passengers, which is rare, I remind myself that the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again!"

At the summer camp where I work, I enjoy watching the children achieve things they never thought they could. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before arriving, but rock climbing is a new challenge for many. Some feel nervous at first, but with encouragement, they try and eventually reach the top, which makes them feel proud. 

At the start of the week, some children miss home, especially those aged ten to thirteen. We limit their mobile phone use; they can call home after lunch, but when they ask again after dinner, we tell them it’s too late and suggest they call the next day. Most children adjust within a couple of days, and by the end of the week, they thank us for a great experience.

Interestingly, it’s not just the children who feel lonely. Some parents frequently call to check on their child, which is often unnecessary. Their child is usually busy playing games or engaging in activities, so we ask the parents to call back later. We also notice a certain type of child who comes dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into more appropriate attire, but they soon understand the reason behind our request.

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors must also be skilled musicians. It opened in London last year after five successful years in the USA, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! However, putting together an all-British cast was challenging. The UK has stricter rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can perform more often. As a result, the production needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors based in the UK, and they recently won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 

The London theatre is larger than the venue in the USA, and it has been full every night, with audiences eager to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He shared how busy the young actors are, mentioning, ‘We have regular school lessons at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ 

I asked Jamie what his classmates thought of the show. He replied, ‘My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, which made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them.’ When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to join him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was relieved that the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes!

Although the young actors were already musicians, some playing multiple instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie admitted that the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
